completed suicide rate among slaves was ~.72 per 100,000 in the USA in 1850: https://scholarworks.montana.edu/xmlui/handle/1/1654 pre-nazi era and nazi era\nthe successful suicide rate among Jews in Germany before the Nazi era was about 27.1-53.2 per 100,000 per year (simple mean (31.5+27.1+33.1+25.0+42.1)/5=31.8); in cities, the rate was 13-67.8 per 100,000 per year (simple mean (67.8+48+13+17+41)/5=37): https://books.google.com/books?id=R1nkj-xSzYgC&pg=PA85 https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/418850379518705675/647811683829415939/lester05_prenazi.png \nthe successful suicide rate among non-deported Jews in Germany during the Nazi era was about 158-317 per 100,000 per year: https://books.google.com/books?id=R1nkj-xSzYgC&pg=PA88 https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/418850379518705675/647811682105819139/lester05_noncamps.png\n\n# holocaust: ghettos\nin the Lodz ghetto, according to a secret Jewish chronicle, completed suicides per 100,000 per year were 21.6 in 1941, 84.6 in 1942, and unknown for 1943-44: https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.2190/E392-DT1H-CWVT-LDUC https://sci-hub.se/10.2190/E392-DT1H-CWVT-LDUC \u0436\u0435\u043b\u0430\u043d\u0438\u044f, \u043a\u043e\u0442\u043e\u0440\u044b\u0435 \u0432\u0430\u043c\u0438 \u0443\u043f\u0440\u0430\u0432\u043b\u044f\u043b\u0438 \u0440\u0430\u043d\u0435\u0435, \u043f\u0440\u0438\u0432\u044b\u0447\u043a\u0430 \u0438\u0441\u043f\u043e\u043b\u044c\u0437\u043e\u0432\u0430\u0442\u044c \u0435\u0434\u0443 \u0434\u043b\u044f \u0440\u0430\u0434\u043e\u0441\u0442\u0438 \u0431\u043e\u043b\u0435\u0435 \u0433\u0443\u0431\u0438\u0442\u0435\u043b\u044c\u043d\u0430, \u0447\u0435\u043c \u043d\u0430\u0441\u0442\u043e\u044f\u0449\u0438\u0435 \u0443\u0432\u043b\u0435\u0447\u0435\u043d\u0438\u044f, \u0432\u044b \u0441\u043c\u043e\u0436\u0435\u0442\u0435 \u043d\u0430 \u043f\u0440\u043e\u0446\u0435\u0441\u0441 \u0433\u043e\u043b\u043e\u0434\u0430\u043d\u0438\u044f \u0432 \u0446\u0435\u043b\u043e\u043c.\n\n\n\u0427\u0442\u043e \u0432\u044b \u0434\u0443\u043c\u0430\u0435\u0442\u0435 \u043f\u043e \u044d\u0442\u043e\u043c\u0443 \u043f\u043e\u0432\u043e\u0434\u0443?\n\n\nImpact of Intermittent Fasting on Health and Disease Processes\nMark P Mattson 1, Valter D Longo 2, Michelle Harvie 3\nAffiliations expand\nPMID: 27810402 PMCID: PMC5411330 DOI: 10.1016/j.arr.2016.10.005\nAbstract\nHumans in modern societies typically consume food at least three times daily, while laboratory animals are fed ad libitum. Overconsumption of food with such eating patterns often leads to metabolic morbidities (insulin resistance, excessive accumulation of visceral fat, etc.), particularly when associated with a sedentary lifestyle. Because animals, including humans, evolved in environments where food was relatively scarce, they developed numerous adaptations that enabled them to function at a high level, both physically and cognitively, when in a food-deprived/fasted state. Intermittent fasting (IF) encompasses eating patterns in which individuals go extended time periods (e.g., 16-48h) with little or no energy intake, with intervening periods of normal food intake, on a recurring basis. We use the term periodic fasting (PF) to refer to IF with periods of fasting or fasting mimicking diets lasting from 2 to as many as 21 or more days. In laboratory rats and mice IF and PF have profound beneficial effects on many different indices of health and, importantly, can counteract disease processes and improve functional outcome in experimental models of a wide range of age-related disorders including diabetes, cardiovascular disease, cancers and neurological disorders such as Alzheimer's disease Parkinson's disease and stroke. Studies of IF (e.g., 60% energy restriction on 2days per week or every other day), PF (e.g., a 5day diet providing 750-1100kcal) and time-restricted feeding (TRF; limiting the daily period of food intake to 8h or less) in normal and overweight human subjects have demonstrated efficacy for weight loss and improvements in multiple health indicators including insulin resistance and reductions in risk factors for cardiovascular disease. The cellular and molecular mechanisms by which IF improves health and counteracts disease processes involve activation of adaptive cellular stress response signaling pathways that enhance mitochondrial health, DNA repair and autophagy. PF also promotes stem cell-based regeneration as well as long-lasting metabolic effects. Randomized controlled clinical trials of IF versus PF and isoenergetic continuous energy restriction in human subjects will be required to establish the efficacy of IF in improving general health, and preventing and managing major diseases of aging", "channelTitle": "Irina Shulkin", "publishedAt": "2020-03-30T06:34:51Z"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "viewCount": "10", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "Rc1o_YAntWE", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT13M55S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2016.10.005", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2016.10.005"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"title": "No BS Nutrition - S2E08 - Intermittent Fasting and Refined vs. Natural Sugars", "description": "Hannah and Tareq discuss a highly-requested topic - Intermittent Fasting! Periodic and Intermittent Fasting Explained. What are the benefits? Is Fasting Sustainable?", "description": "There are two types of fasting. Periodic fasting and Intermittent fasting. What are the benefits of fasting and is it sustainable?\nFirstly, the most popular version of Periodic fasting is Time-Restricted feeding. This is where you fast for 16 hours and eat within a window of 8 hours. This looks like eating your evening meal by 6pm at night, and not eating again until 10 am the next morning and then eating your normal diet, preferably modelled on the Mediterranean diet throughout that next eight hours. Dr Valter Longo recommends that 12-13 hours of fasting is safe and manageable and has found that people do better with this way of eating - it also prevents gall stone formation that the longer hours of fasting may promote.\nThe other version of periodic fasting incorporates for example, a 5 day diet providing 750-1100kcal and this is called the fasting mimicking diet. It is suggested by Dr Valter Longo that this is an effective way of fasting and is great to do 2-3 times a year and the diet his fasting diet is a vegan diet made up of fat 45%, Carbs 45% and Protein 10%. He has a book that you can check out called The Longevity Diet. \nThe second is Intermittent fasting (IF) that encompasses eating patterns in which individuals go extended time periods (e.g., 16-48h) with little or no energy intake, with intervening periods of normal food intake, on a recurring basis. \nHealth Benefits\nLifestyle behaviours such as, intermittent fasting and caloric restriction, and  exercise trigger the activity of sirtuins, restoring normal gene regulation, resetting the cell's activity, and slowing the aging process. There are a number of disorders this affects such as for several human disorders, including infections and inflammatory diseases, neurodegeneration, metabolic and cardiovascular diseases, obesity and cancer. \nDr Valter Longo suggest that Fasting \u2013 cleans house in the body and is a powerful way to treat disease and prevent cancer.  His research also suggests that the Fasting Mimicking Diet and Cancer treatment (drug therapy) in combination are very effective in providing a good outcome for the patient.\nSustainability\nModifiable lifestyle adjustments such as smoking cessation, increasing movement, ensuring proper body weight all assist in reducing the risk of cardiovascular disease. True, NoSQL databases are more scalable, handle unstructured data better, and often perform faster than relational databases (Schulz, Nelson, Felker, Durant, & Torres, 2016). However, despite their obvious deficiency handling unstructured data, relational databases still have valid use-cases in the modern enterprise (Leavitt, 2010). I believe that relational databases will stick around in conjunction with NoSQL for years. \nReferences\nSchulz, W. L., Nelson, B. G., Felker, D. K., Durant, T. J., & Torres, R. (2016). Retrieved from http://diyhpl.us/~nmz787/biological%20radio%20research/Electromagnetic%20Radiation%20and%20Human%20Health__A%20Review%20of%20Sources%20and%20Effects__Fluor%20Corporation.pdf", "channelTitle": "Demystifying Medicine", "publishedAt": "2018-04-02T15:15:12Z"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "35", "viewCount": "4576", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "19", "commentCount": "24"}, "id": "qa5BmRfRfjo", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT6M35S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2016.10.018", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2016.10.018"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"tags": ["Osteoporosis exercises to avoid", "osteoporosis spinal rotation and spinal fracture", "vertebral compression fractures", "osteoporosis spine", "osteoporosis in the spine exercises to avoid", "Pilates and exercises to avoid", "exercises to avoid with osteoporosis", "osteoporosis and exercise", "spinal wedge fracture", "physiotherapy", "physical therapy"], "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "defaultLanguage": "en", "channelId": "UCPQS5BOA_GLQKCc07ZCOjJg", "title": "4 Exercises You Should AVOID For Osteoporosis Spinal Fracture", "description": "This Physiotherapy video guides you through 4 exercises to avoid that can increase the risk of spinal fracture if you have high fracture with osteoporosis. Some of these exercises to avoid are commonplace in fitness centers and some exercise classes (e.g. Yoga and Pilates). Knowing how to modify potentially unsafe exercises can help you exercise safely and reduce the risk of spinal fracture with osteoporosis.\n\nWebsite: https://www.pelvicexercises.com.au\n\nExercise 1: Forward Bends\nExercises that involve bending forwards can increase the risk of having a spinal wedge or compression fracture with severe osteoporosis (Vertebral T-score less than \u22122.5 SD). A spinal compression fracture occurs when the vertebra are soft and brittle. Bending forwards compresses the vertebra which can cause them to become squashed and fracture with severely decreased bone density. Exercises such as abdominal curls and deep forward bend in Yoga compress the vertebra together. These exercises are easily modified with to reduce the risk of fracture.\n\nExercise 2: Loaded Forward Bends\nLoaded forward bends further increase the risk of spinal wedge fracture and are therefore unsafe osteoporosis exercises. The risk of osteoporosis fracture increases the further forward you bend and the heavier the weight you lift.\n\nExercise 3:  Spinal Rotation\nYour spinal vertebra rotate during normal movement however some spinal rotation exercises can increase the risk of spinal fracture. Parts of the vertebra are forced against each other when the spine rotates to extreme ranges. Examples of extreme range spinal twisting exercises to avoid with severe osteoporosis include full range lumbar rotation exercises taking the knees right across to the ground and abdominal curl exercises that are combined with spinal rotations.\n\nExercise 4: Direct Spinal Loading\nSome gym exercises for the legs and back involve placing a weighted bar at the top of the spine and across the shoulders. This force on the upper spine travels down through the vertebra and the load can compress soft brittle vertebrae causing a compression fracture. These unsafe osteoporosis exercises are readily modified \n\nIf you're currently doing any of these exercises and you have a high risk of spinal fracture with osteoporosis it's worth stopping these exercises now and discussing whether they're appropriate for your condition with your health professional.\n\n#osteoporosisexercises  #osteoporosis #spinalfracture\n\n\nReferences\nBeck BR1, Daly RM2, Singh MA3, Taaffe DR4. (2017) Exercise and Sports Science Australia (ESSA) position statement on exercise prescription for the prevention and management of osteoporosis. J Sci Med Sport. 2017 May;20(5):438-445. doi: 10.1016/j.jsams.2016.10.001. Epub 2016 Oct 31.\n\nImage spinal fracture https://www.injurymap.com/free-human-anatomy-illustrations\n- - - - - - - - \nMusic by Aiden Kenway https://aidenkenway.com/ \n- - - - - - - - \nDisclaimer \nThe information provided in this video is intended as general information and not a substitute for individual medical advice regarding your medical condition. Accordingly, in many \nparts  of  the  world  increased  methamphetamine  use  has  \nbeen identified as a major public health concern. Treatment \nprograms  for  methamphetamine  have  been  effective  in  \nreducing  and  ceasing  use.  However,  there  are  a  range  of  \npossible   barriers   that   have   prevented   these   programs   \nbeing  widely  adopted  by  methamphetamine  users.  This  \nseminar  presents  findings  from  a  systematic  review  and  \nmeta-analysis  that  examined  the  barriers  to  accessing  \nmeth/amphetamine  treatment  reported  in  peer-reviewed  \nliterature.  Strategies  to  improve  access,  engagement,  and  \nretention in appropriately tailored treatment programs for \namphetamine dependent individuals will be discussed.  \n\n:: About the Speaker\nJesse Young is a Research Fellow and PhD Candidate at the \nCentre  for  Mental  Health,  The  University  of  Melbourne.  \nHe holds adjunct Research Fellow positions at the School \nof Population Health, The University of Western Australia \nand the National Drug Research Institute, Curtin University. \n\nFind the full paper here:\nCumming, C., Troeung, L., Young, J. Written language only began at around 3200 BC, but spoken language has existed long ago.\r\n\r\nLearning by listening is a great way to:\r\n- increases imagination and understanding\r\n- improves your listening skills\r\n- improves your own spoken accent\r\n- learn while on the move\r\n- reduce eye strain\r\n\r\nNow learn the vast amount of general knowledge available on Wikipedia through audio (audio article). You could even learn subconsciously by playing the audio while you are sleeping! If you are planning to listen a lot, you could try using a bone conduction headphone, or a standard speaker instead of an earphone.\r\n\r\nYou can find other Wikipedia audio articles too at:\r\nhttps://www.youtube.com/channel/UCuKfABj2eGyjH3ntPxp4YeQ\r\n\r\nYou can upload your own Wikipedia articles through:\r\nhttps://github.com/nodef/wikipedia-tts\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\"The only true wisdom is in knowing you know nothing.\"\r\n- Socrates\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSUMMARY\r\n=======\r\nWilliam Whewell  ( HEW-\u0259l; 24 May 1794 \u2013 6 March 1866) was an English polymath, scientist, Anglican priest, philosopher, theologian, and historian of science. He was Master of Trinity College, Cambridge.  In his time as a student there, he achieved distinction in both poetry and mathematics.\nWhat is most often remarked about Whewell is the breadth of his endeavours.  In a time of increasing specialisation, Whewell appears as a vestige of an earlier era when natural philosophers dabbled in a bit of everything. He researched ocean tides (for which he won the Royal Medal), published work in the disciplines of mechanics, physics, geology, astronomy, and economics, while also finding the time to compose poetry, author a Bridgewater Treatise, translate the works of Goethe, and write sermons and theological tracts.  In mathematics, Whewell introduced what is now called the Whewell equation, an equation defining the shape of a curve without reference to an arbitrarily chosen coordinate system.\nOne of Whewell's greatest gifts to science was his wordsmithing.  He often corresponded with many in his field and helped them come up with new terms for their discoveries.  Whewell contributed the terms scientist, physicist, linguistics, consilience, catastrophism, uniformitarianism, and astigmatism amongst others; Whewell suggested the terms electrode, ion, dielectric, anode, and cathode to Michael Faraday.Whewell died in Cambridge in 1866 as a result of a fall from his horse.", "channelTitle": "wikipedia tts", "publishedAt": "2018-11-25T01:51:09Z"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "viewCount": "89", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "mV8V2fnO_8U", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT21M3S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.ins.2016.10.001", "q": "10.1016/j.ins.2016.10.001"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"tags": ["#hangoutsonair", "Hangouts On Air", "#hoa", "#hangoutsonair", "Hangouts On Air", "#hoa"], "channelId": "UCThKIBfGCHfTP5ZvE_J3ZzA", "title": "Cl\u00e9ment Buonanno", "description": "Sanders, T. This video looks at two siblings who were separated at birth and exposed to different environmental influencers and familial lifestyles. You may have heard that the eyes are the window to the brain. This is because your eyes are direct extensions of your brain that sprout out during development. Then, we rely on our visual system to tell us where we are in space and what is around us. In order to map our world, we need the ability to move our eyes to see it. This requires a large amount of brain activity from many areas that are interconnected through brain circuits. When one part of the brain is not functioning well, we can identify and rehabilitate that area via eye movements. Check out the video for more in depth information on the different types of eye movements and how they can be used for diagnosis and treatment!\nLappi, O. "oPf3iZHQaXU", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT32S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.is.2016.04.006", "q": "10.1016/j.is.2016.04.006"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"tags": ["Visualization", "Annotations", "Meta-Analysis", "Graph-Based Visualization"], "channelId": "UC5eDbWA__4auvubi911Gkrw", "title": "Annotation Graphs: A Graph-Based Visualization for Meta-Analysis of Data", "description": "User-authored annotations of data can support analysts in the activity of hypothesis generation and sensemaking, where it is not only critical to document key observations, but also to communicate insights between analysts. We present annotation graphs, a dynamic graph visualization that enables meta-analysis of data based on user-authored annotations. The annotation graph topology encodes annotation semantics, which describe the content of and relations between data selections, comments, and tags. We present a mixed-initiative approach to graph layout that integrates an analyst\u2019s manual manipulations with an automatic method based on similarity inferred from the annotation semantics. Various visual graph layout styles reveal different perspectives on the annotation semantics. Annotation graphs are implemented within C8, a system that supports authoring annotations during exploratory analysis of a dataset. We apply principles of Exploratory Sequential Data Analysis (ESDA) in designing C8, and further link these to an existing task typology in the visualization literature. We develop and evaluate the system through an iterative user-centered design process with three experts, situated in the domain of analyzing HCI experiment data. The results suggest that annotation graphs are effective as a method of visually extending user-authored annotations to data meta-analysis for discovery and organization of ideas.\n\nhttps://autodeskresearch.com/publications/annotation-graphs\n\n_________________________________\n\nJian Zhao, Michael Glueck, Simon Breslav, Fanny Chevalier, Azam Khan (2016) Annotation Graphs: A Graph-Based Visualization for Meta-Analysis of Data based on User-Authored Annotations. IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics. To appear.\n\nhttp://dx.doi.org/10.1109/TVCG.2016.2598543\n\nAutodesk Research\nhttp://www.autodeskresearch.com", "channelTitle": "Autodesk Research", "publishedAt": "2016-10-31T19:35:46Z"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "4", "viewCount": "843", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "VHYQiB9X2II", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT4M7S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1109/TVCG.2016.2598543", "q": "10.1109/TVCG.2016.2598543"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"tags": ["Autodesk Research", "Visualization", "Visual Analytics", "Phenotypes", "Cross-Sectional Cohort", "Hierarchy Comparison", "Human Phenotype Ontology", "IEEE VAST 2016", "PhenoStacks"], "channelId": "UC5eDbWA__4auvubi911Gkrw", "title": "PhenoStacks: Cross-Sectional Cohort Phenotype Comparison Visualizations", "description": "Cross-sectional phenotype studies are used by genetics researchers to better understand how phenotypes vary across patients with genetic diseases, both within and between cohorts. Analyses within cohorts identify patterns between phenotypes and patients (e.g., co-occurrence) and isolate special cases (e.g., potential outliers). Comparing the variation of phenotypes between two cohorts can help distinguish how different factors affect disease manifestation (e.g., causal genes, age of onset, etc.). PhenoStacks is a novel visual analytics tool that supports the exploration of phenotype variation within and between cross-sectional patient cohorts. By leveraging the semantic hierarchy of the Human Phenotype Ontology, phenotypes are presented in context, can be grouped and clustered, and are summarized via overviews to support the exploration of phenotype distributions. The design of PhenoStacks was motivated by formative interviews with genetics researchers: we distil high-level tasks, present an algorithm for simplifying ontology topologies for visualization, and report the results of a deployment evaluation with four expert genetics researchers. The results suggest that PhenoStacks can help identify phenotype patterns, investigate data quality issues, and inform data collection design.\n\nhttps://www.autodeskresearch.com/publications/phenostacks\n\n_________________________________\n\nGlueck, M., Gvozdik, A., Chevalier, F., Khan, A., Brudno, M., & Wigdor, D. (2017). PhenoStacks: cross-sectional cohort phenotype comparison visualizations. IEEE transactions on visualization and computer graphics, 23(1), 191-200.\n\nhttp://dx.doi.org/10.1109/TVCG.2016.2598469\n\nAutodesk Research\nhttp://www.autodeskresearch.com", "channelTitle": "Autodesk Research", "publishedAt": "2016-10-31T19:18:00Z"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "2", "viewCount": "294", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "Uz6J50ppct4", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT3M17S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1109/TVCG.2016.2598469", "q": "10.1109/TVCG.2016.2598469"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"tags": ["Revista Espa\u00f1ola de Cardiolog\u00eda", "Rev Esp Cardiol", "V\u00eddeo", "Infarto agudo de miocardio con elevaci\u00f3n de segmento ST", "Estrategias de reperfusi\u00f3n", "Intervenci\u00f3n coronaria percut\u00e1nea primaria", "Fibrinolisis", "Pol\u00edticas de salud", "Redes de IAMCEST", "Cequier"], "defaultAudioLanguage": "es", "channelId": "UCsySMJfKVnZZudEJCKy8wHA", "title": "A. Cequier.  Mortalidad por SCACEST y sistemas de asistencia en red", "description": "Entrevista al Dr. \u00c1ngel Cequier sobre su art\u00edculo Impacto en la mortalidad de diferentes sistemas de asistencia en red para el tratamiento del infarto agudo de miocardio con elevaci\u00f3n del segmento ST. La experiencia de Espa\u00f1a, publicado en el n\u00famero de marzo de 2017 en Rev Esp Cardiol. DOI: 10.1016/j.recesp.2016.07.016", "channelTitle": "Sociedad Espa\u00f1ola de Cardiolog\u00eda", "publishedAt": "2017-02-24T07:50:25Z"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "3", "viewCount": "577", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "1"}, "id": "gvzY-8xhiVg", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT7M34S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.cor.2016.07.016", "q": "10.1016/j.cor.2016.07.016"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"tags": ["Cognitive Therapy for social anxiety", "CBT"], "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelId": "UCj7UE3C6UMe5_RC7_V5PM-g", "title": "Video Feedback in Cognitive Therapy for Social Anxiety (demo clip)", "description": "7-minute video clip that illustrates some of the procedures described for using video feedback in cognitive therapy for social anxiety disorder. The role-played clip is based on a real cognitive therapy session that took 90 minutes. The clip illustrates: (1) Identifying a patient\u2019s predictions in advance of viewing a video; (2) Preparing the patient to view the video; (3) Discussing the video and rewinding to capture key moments; (4) Comparing ratings before and after viewing the video; and (5) Freezing the moment of disconfirmation and consolidating learning. \n\nVideo patients/clients are portrayed by actors.\n\nCreative Commons licence Attribution 4.0 International (CC BY 4.0). https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/\n\nThis is an excerpt from a journal article. The full journal publication can be downloaded from: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cbpra.2016.03.007\n\nREFERENCE\nCognitive and Behavioral Practice. Volume 24, Issue 2, May 2017, Pages 245-255. \u05d4\u05d7\u05d5\u05dc\u05d9\u05dd \u05d4\u05e1\u05d5\u05d1\u05dc\u05d9\u05dd \u05de\u05d4\u05e9\u05de\u05e0\u05ea \u05d9\u05ea\u05e8 \u05d9\u05e9 \u05e8\u05de\u05d5\u05ea \u05d4\u05d1\u05d9\u05df-\u05d0\u05d9\u05e9\u05d9\u05ea \u05d1\u05e8\u05d2\u05d9\u05e9\u05d5\u05ea J Am Coll Cardiol. 2016;doi:10.1016/j.jacc.2016.03.004\n\nhttp://content.onlinejacc.org/article.aspx?articleid=2510813#tab1", "channelTitle": "CSWNews", "publishedAt": "2016-04-11T20:02:19Z"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "viewCount": "88", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "PxjqY9T6h50", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT6M19S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.im.2016.03.004", "q": "10.1016/j.im.2016.03.004"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"title": "CVIU 2016: A real-time Human-Robot Interaction system based on gestures for assistive scenarios", "description": "Demo video for the paper:\nGerard Canal, Sergio Escalera, Cecilio Angulo, A real-time Human-Robot Interaction system based on gestures for assistive scenarios, Computer Vision and Image Understanding, Volume 149, August 2016, Pages 65-77, ISSN 1077-3142, http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cviu.2016.03.004.\n\n\nAbstract:\nNatural and intuitive human interaction with robotic systems is a key point to develop robots assisting people in an easy and effective way. In this paper, a Human Robot Interaction (HRI) system able to recognize gestures usually employed in human non-verbal communication is introduced, and an in-depth study of its usability is performed. The system deals with dynamic gestures such as waving or nodding which are recognized using a Dynamic Time Warping approach based on gesture specific features computed from depth maps. A static gesture consisting in pointing at an object is also recognized. The pointed location is then estimated in order to detect candidate objects the user may refer to. When the pointed object is unclear for the robot, a disambiguation procedure by means of either a verbal or gestural dialogue is performed. This skill would lead to the robot picking an object in behalf of the user, which could present difficulties to do it by itself. The overall system \u2014 which is composed by a NAO and Wifibot robots, a KinectTM v2 sensor and two laptops \u2014 is firstly evaluated in a structured lab setup. Then, a broad set of user tests has been completed, which allows to assess correct performance in terms of recognition rates, easiness of use and response times.", "channelId": "UC5l4gXBnV1GHAQMPwA0RgpQ", "publishedAt": "2017-05-31T14:10:30Z", "channelTitle": "Gerard Canal"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "viewCount": "106", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "E91s8X9Gymk", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1M47S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.im.2016.03.004", "q": "10.1016/j.im.2016.03.004"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"tags": ["scilabus", "syllabus", "covid", "corona", "coronavirus", "respirateur", "respiration", "soigner", "patient", "open source", "ingenierie", "ingenieur", "concours", "design", "conception", "g\u00e9nie mecanique", "process", "processus", "ballon masque", "pand\u00e9mie"], "defaultAudioLanguage": "fr", "defaultLanguage": "fr", "channelId": "UCeR8BYZS7IHYjk_9Mh5JgkA", "title": "Comment concevoir un respirateur en deux semaines ?", "description": "Comment peut-on concevoir un respirateur alors que cela prend 3 \u00e0 7 ans d'habitude ? There exists a great variety in type, the setup of the cushion and how its fits to the final user. In general, all types of cushion can be distinguished by material (foam, gel, air cells and hybrids), dimension (size and thickness), contour, interface and stiffness. In the presented study the influences of general parameters such as dimension, friction and stiffness are investigated for a simple foam setup. In addition, the influence of posture and anthropometrics is analyzed. In order to reduce time and cost, the analysis was carried out with using Finite Element Analysis. Therefore 3D human body models are applied, which is more or less a standard in the automotive sector to evaluate and optimize car seats. FEA provides reproducible data about result values as immersion and pressure distribution. Further, FEA is used in other industries to analyze the internal behavior of body structures. The computed internal tissue strains can be used to visualize and analyze the Volumetric Strain Distribution (VSD), a quantitative value for the risk evaluation of pressure ulcers. Finally, each parameter and its influence on relevant assessment values will be analyzed and presented. Based on these general conclusions, we can improve our understanding of the mechanical interaction between the human body and the wheelchair cushion.\n\nLearning Objectives:\n\nDiscuss two different clinical applications of how the defined cushion parameters influence critical values as pressure distribution, immersion and volumetric strain distribution\nDescribe at least two benefits of using FEA for cushion evaluation\nList three different clinical strategies on how to decrease internal tissue load with postural variation\n\nPresenters:\n\nAlexander Siefert, PhD\nW\u00f6lfel Engineering GmbH & Co.kg, Germany\n\nAlexander Siefert is working at W\u00f6lfel since 2003 at leads currently the seating department as an engineering director. He made his PHD at the TU Darmstadt about the topic: \"Numerical modelling of mechanical properties of the human tissue and its implementation in a whole body model\". He published several papers in the field of human body modelling and made a lot of presentation on international conferences about seating, human modelling and pressure sores.\n\nBart Van Der Heyden, PT\nPrivate PT Practice: De Kine SuperSeating, Belgium\n\nBart Van der Heyden is an independent physical therapist specializing in wheelchair seating & mobility as well as wound care with 25 years of experience and over 20 years of experience mentoring service providers. Bart is licensed and has practiced as a physical therapist across Europe and the United States. Based in Belgium, he travels the world for lectures, educational events, and hands on sessions to varied audiences on seating and mobility issues, the provision of wheelchair equipment for children and adults with moderate to severe physical challenges, and wound related problems. Bart maintains his skills and experience by continuing to work in his private practice. He is also a clinical consultant on clinical applications, design, and functionality of medical devices for several wheelchair manufacturers and has conducted clinical studies for these companies as well. His expertise lies in client and service provider training and education, spasticity management, pediatrics, wound care and evidence based clinical decision making.\n\nReferences:\n\nOomens, C., Broek, M., Hemmes, B., & Bader, D. Virtual Human Model CASIMIR - A Chance and a Challenge for the Aetiology Understanding of Pressure Injury Development, Proceedings Science of Experience Conference, Boston", "channelTitle": "RSTCE", "publishedAt": "2019-06-27T14:51:41Z"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "viewCount": "177", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "_OIdlxu3Fkc", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT52M55S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.im.2016.03.009", "q": "10.1016/j.im.2016.03.009"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"title": "Session 1   Trends that shape the future", "description": "In this session we address the 50-year old predictions of Limits to Growth and how the authors perceived the human predicament. I check whether their expectations were realistic by focussing on the difference between problem prevention and problem solving, applied to a number of clear human achievements. This then leads to a the role and structure of social values. Humans can exhibit multiple different value sets, but the currently dominant value set is very good in solving (isolated) problem, but bad in preventing problems. This leads to the hypothesis that humanity is concurrently at peak foolishness and peak intelligence. And hence ill-prepared for any future different than business as usual. \n\nReferences:\n\n- Andringa, T. C., & Angyal, N. (2019). Os curcumin\u00f3ides s\u00e3o compostos fen\u00f3licos comumente usados \u200b\u200bcomo tempero, pigmento e aditivo, tamb\u00e9m utilizados como agente terap\u00eautico usado em v\u00e1rios alimentos. Pesquisas\ud83d\udd2c abrangentes ao longo do s\u00e9culo passado revelaram v\u00e1rias fun\u00e7\u00f5es importantes dos curcumin\u00f3ides\ud83e\udd17.\n\nV\u00e1rios estudos \ud83d\udcd6\ud83e\uddeapr\u00e9-cl\u00ednicos de cultura de c\u00e9lulas e animais sugerem que os curcumin\u00f3ides t\u00eam extensa atividade biol\u00f3gica como antioxidante, neuroprotetor, antitumor, anti-inflamat\u00f3rio, anti-acidog\u00eanico, radioprotetor e artrite\ud83d\ude33.\n\nDiferentes ensaios cl\u00ednicos\ud83d\udd2c\ud83e\uddea tamb\u00e9m sugerem um potencial papel terap\u00eautico para os curcumin\u00f3ides em in\u00fameras doen\u00e7as cr\u00f4nicas, como c\u00e2ncer de c\u00f3lon , c\u00e2ncer de pulm\u00e3o, c\u00e2ncer de mama, doen\u00e7as inflamat\u00f3rias intestinais.\n\nOs curcumin\u00f3ides s\u00e3o o composto natural \ud83c\udf3f\ud83c\udf43promissor com uma grande variedade de propriedades terap\u00eauticas, principalmente alvos e intera\u00e7\u00f5es biol\u00f3gicas, ligados a in\u00fameras doen\u00e7as.\n\nNa revis\u00e3o \ud83d\udcd6 realizada pelo Centro R&D da Aurea Biolabs na India em 2016 os pesquisadores destacam as propriedades dos curcumin\u00f3ides, no uso isolado ou em associa\u00e7\u00e3o com outra forma modificada, demonstrando serem eficazes no tratamento neuroprotetor, antitumoral, antioxidante, anticancer\u00edgeno, anti-inflamat\u00f3rio, anti-acidog\u00eanico, radioprotetor, infec\u00e7\u00f5es sexualmente transmiss\u00edveis, anti-esof\u00e1gico, anti-nefrotoxicidade, antimicrobiano, antiviral, anti-angiog\u00eanico, anti-proliferativo, anti-imunomodulador, hepatoprotetor, antimal\u00e1rico, anti-toxicidade e propriedades anti-diab\u00e9ticas. \ud83d\ude0d\n\nFonte: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jtcme.2016.05.005\n\nPara saber mais sobre o PODER DOS \u00d3LEOS ESSENCIAIS\ud83c\udf43 \u00e9 s\u00f3 chamar!\n\nGostou? deixe seu coment\u00e1rio e compartilhe com que voc\u00ea ama!\u2764", "channelTitle": "Dra. Wood"], "channelId": "UCTeBCA-JF6pXl4OSY_4yKpw", "title": "C\u00fa-lt podcast epis\u00f3dio 7- O conceito de Trash", "description": "Epis\u00f3dio no qual discutimos os conceitos de trash, cult e "10.1016/j.im.2016.04.002"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"tags": ["magic mushrooms", "psilocin", "neuroscience", "brain", "psychedelic"], "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelId": "UCUgZq9PkDp1xaEivtcfJPSg", "title": "2-Minute Neuroscience: Psilocybin", "description": "Psilocybin is a substance found in a number of mushroom species that can be ingested to cause psychoactive effects. Although psilocybin itself is thought to have very little (if any) psychoactive effects, upon ingestion it is rapidly metabolized into a highly psychoactive substance called psilocin. In this video, I discuss our understanding of psilocin\u2019s effects on the brain.\n\nTRANSCRIPT:\n\nPsilocybin is a substance found in a number of mushroom species that can be ingested to cause psychoactive effects. It is considered a psychedelic or hallucinogenic drug with some similarities to LSD in terms of effects.\n\nPsilocybin itself is not thought to be very psychoactive, but soon after it is ingested it is metabolized into a substance called psilocin, which is highly psychoactive. Psilocybin is thus considered a prodrug, or a substance that is inactive until converted into an active drug after administration. Although we have some understanding of the activity of psilocin in the brain, it is not fully understood how this activity leads to the subjective experiences people have while taking psilocybin. Regardless, it is thought that psilocin\u2019s activity at a subtype of serotonin receptor known as the 5-HT2A receptor is critical to the drug\u2019s psychedelic effects. Psilocin is thought to act as a partial agonist at the 5-HT2A receptor, which means that it binds to the 5-HT2A receptor and causes a response that is a fraction of what the natural ligand, serotonin, does. Psilocin also interacts with other targets, like other serotonin receptor subtypes, some subtypes of dopamine, histamine, and adrenergic receptors, and the serotonin transporter. The role of these other targets in the effects of psilocybin, however, is not very clear. \n\nLike many other psychedelic drugs, repeated administration of psilocybin over multiple days leads to rapid tolerance and substantially reduced effectiveness. This tolerance is thought to be associated with the down-regulation, or decrease in number, of 5-HT2A serotonin receptors. Psilocybin also exhibits cross-tolerance with LSD, meaning that if someone develops tolerance to one of these drugs, they may display tolerance to the other---regardless of their history with the other drug. Psilocybin, however, is not generally considered to be addictive and is thought to be safe in terms of its effects on the body.\n\nReferences:\n\nGeiger HA, Wurst MG, Daniels RN. DARK Classics in Chemical Neuroscience: Psilocybin. ACS Chem Neurosci. 2018 Oct 17;9(10):2438-2447. doi: 10.1021/acschemneuro.8b00186. Epub 2018 Jul 16.\n\nNichols DE.Psychedelics. Pharmacol Rev. 2016 Apr;68(2):264-355. doi: 10.1124/pr.115.011478.\n\nRickli A, Moning OD, Hoener MC, Liechti ME. Receptor interaction profiles of novel psychoactive tryptamines compared with classic hallucinogens. Eur Neuropsychopharmacol. 2016 Aug;26(8):1327-37. doi: 10.1016/j.euroneuro.2016.05.001. Epub 2016 May 20.\n\nTyl\u0161 F, P\u00e1len\u00ed\u010dek T, Hor\u00e1\u010dek J. Psilocybin--summary of knowledge and new perspectives. Eur Neuropsychopharmacol. 2014 Mar;24(3):342-56. doi: 10.1016/j.euroneuro.2013.12.006. Epub 2013 Dec 17.", "channelTitle": "Neuroscientifically Challenged", "publishedAt": "2020-05-05T10:36:43Z"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "276", "viewCount": "8006", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "3", "commentCount": "40"}, "id": "XBEas8MGzd0", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M1S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.im.2016.05.001", "q": "10.1016/j.im.2016.05.001"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"tags": ["McMaster University", "Demystifying Medicine", "colonic", "colon", "colonic hydrotherapy", "gut", "gut health", "IBD", "natural", "McMaster", "student"], "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelId": "UCEwEYnO7yey-oBzyNu-AauQ", "title": "Washing out your gut ... beneficial or harmful?", "description": "This video sheds light on a procedure being done by many people: colonics, also known as colonic hydrotherapy. This video discusses claims made by proponents of colonics and explains why the science does not back them up. We will also discuss how the colon works and how to keep your gut health naturally. The video features an interview with a postdoctoral fellow and professor at McMaster University who conduct research on gut health and diseases like irritable bowel disease. \n\nThis video was made by McMaster students Sundas, Abhiti, Veronica and Nirushaa.\n\nCopyright McMaster University 2019.\n\nBackground music was downloaded from Bensound.com.\n\nReferences:\n\nConlon, M. A., & Bird, A. R. (2015, December 24). The impact of diet and lifestyle on gut microbiota and human health. Nutrients. MDPI AG. https://doi.org/10.3390/nu7010017\n\nChoudhary, R., & Tandon, R. V. Retrieved from https://journals-scholarsportal-info.libaccess.lib.mcmaster.ca/pdf/14733099/v05i0008/527_eafch.xml", "channelTitle": "Demystifying Medicine", "publishedAt": "2019-11-28T04:04:32Z"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "4", "viewCount": "60", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "oQe7XTqrz1I", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT8M33S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.im.2016.05.001", "q": "10.1016/j.im.2016.05.001"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"tags": ["quantified self", "chocolate", "cacao", "science", "blood pressure", "happiness", "stress", "productivity"], "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelId": "UChNWxrTlmh4IRSevon1X93g", "title": "Effects of dark chocolate according to science: tracking my chocolate consumption for over a year", "description": "I always wondered what effect chocolate has on my body and mind. To find out, I tracked my chocolate eating habits and my mental and physical health for over a year. In this vlog I discuss what I found!\n\nThis vlog is part of a big scientific project where I track everything in my life. This includes weekly brain MRI\u2019s, weekly sleep EEGs and daily microbiome samples. If you would like to get frequent updates on my project, also consider subscribing to my Instagram.\n\nFollow me:\nTwitter: https://twitter.com/Quant_Scientist\nInstagram: http://instagram.com/quantified_scientist\n\nI am a scientist, and I specialise in data-analysis of immunological data (the immune system). This also means I am not an expert on chocolate and its effects. All the facts I mention about chocolate come from scientific literature, some of which will be more reliable than others. If you have any suggestions, please leave them in the comments below!\n\nAs with all science, not of mine findings are 100% definitive. Results will have to be replicated and possible causal relationships validated. The associations I found with chocolate also have some limitations. The most important is that I only tracked happiness for the last four months mentioned in the vlog, which means that the number of data-points is rather limited. I did track productivity and stress over a much longer period, and blood pressure was tracked throughout the whole period mentioned in the vlog. Also, I have continued tracking my chocolate eating and all these factors after the mentioned period. So, this data can be used to validate my findings.\n\nI was not paid by any chocolate manufacturer for any of the statements made in this vlog.\n\n\n--Scientific papers--\nI used PubMed to search for scientific literature. (2016). doi:10.1016/j.tifs.2016.05.001\n\n--Clips used\u2014\n\u201cCould I interest you in some chocolate\u201d & Screaming chocolate guy \u2013 Spongebob Squarepants (Bikini Bottom Mysteries Ep. 9)\nBoy finishing a platter of chocolate cake \u2013 Bruce vs Chocolate cake scene \u201cMatilda\u201d (1996)\nMan whistling for chocolate (Black and White) \u2013 Alfred Hitchcock \u201cSecret Agent\u201d (1936)\n\u201cWhere is the chocolate\u201d \u2013 Wonka vision scene, \u201cWilly Wonka and the Chocolate factory\u201d (1971)\n\u201cWould you like a chocolate\u201d \u2013 Forrest Gump (1994)", "channelTitle": "The Quantified Scientist", "publishedAt": "2019-09-22T23:32:45Z"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "73", "viewCount": "1209", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "commentCount": "28"}, "id": "GuvZoMDY0C8", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT11M9S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.im.2016.05.001", "q": "10.1016/j.im.2016.05.001"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"tags": ["acid", "lysergic acid diethylamide", "hallucinogen", "psychedelic", "tripping", "neuroscience", "brain"], "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelId": "UCUgZq9PkDp1xaEivtcfJPSg", "title": "2-Minute Neuroscience: LSD", "description": "Lysergic acid diethylamide, or LSD, is a potent psychoactive substance that is commonly classified as a hallucinogen or psychedelic drug. In this video, I discuss our understanding of LSD's effects on the brain.\n\nTRANSCRIPT:\n\nLysergic acid diethylamide, or LSD, is a potent psychoactive substance that is commonly classified as a hallucinogen or psychedelic drug. The effects of LSD vary substantially depending on the dose, the mood of the individual taking the drug, and the environment the drug is taken in. Some common effects include mental and physical stimulation, perceptual distortions, and generally positive mood states.\n\nAlthough we have some understanding of LSD\u2019s activity in the brain, it is not fully understood how this activity leads to the subjective experiences people have while taking the drug. Regardless, it is thought that LSD\u2019s activity at a subtype of serotonin receptor known as the 5-HT2A receptor is critical to the drug\u2019s psychedelic effects. LSD acts as a partial agonist at the 5-HT2A receptor, which means that it binds to the 5-HT2A receptor and generates a response that is a fraction of what the natural ligand, serotonin, generates. LSD also interacts with other receptors, although the role of these receptors in the effects of LSD is less clear. For example, LSD binds to other serotonin receptor subtypes as well as some subtypes of dopamine and adrenergic receptors. Research suggests that one large-scale effect of LSD on the brain is increased glutamate transmission in the frontal cortex, which is thought to play a role in the effects of LSD. \n\nRepeated administration of LSD over several days promotes rapid tolerance, where the drug has much less of an effect than it did initially. This tolerance is thought to be associated with the down-regulation, or decrease in number, of 5-HT2A serotonin receptors. LSD is not, however, considered to be addictive. And, although it is a potent drug, it is generally considered to be non-toxic and safe in terms of its effects on the body. \n\nReferences:\n\nLiechti ME. Modern Clinical Research on LSD. Neuropsychopharmacology. 2017 Oct;42(11):2114-2127. doi: 10.1038/npp.2017.86. Epub 2017 Apr 27.\n\nNichols DE. Psychedelics. Pharmacol Rev. 2016 Apr;68(2):264-355. doi: 10.1124/pr.115.011478.\n\nRickli A, Moning OD, Hoener MC, Liechti ME. Receptor interaction profiles of novel psychoactive tryptamines compared with classic hallucinogens. Eur Neuropsychopharmacol. 2016 Aug;26(8):1327-37. doi: 10.1016/j.euroneuro.2016.05.001. Clinical practice guidelines for South African paramedics has recently been updated and is being implemented nationally, however implementation by industry and decision makers needs to be strengthened further.  To address this, researchers from Stellenbosch University have conducted studies to strengthen guideline uptake by identifying prehospital end-users\u2019 perceptions of the guidelines, including barriers and facilitators for national decision makers. Treatment? Prevention?  Chlamydia infects both men and women.", "description": "Chlamydia. What are the symptoms? How is Chlamydia treated? What can be done to prevent Chlamydia in both men and women?  \n\nThere is something like 20 different types of STI\u2019s but, they come in 3 flavours:\n1. Parasitic: Scabies and pubic lice, these can be cured\n2. Bacterial: Chlamydia, Gonorrhoea and Syphilis, these can be cured.\n3. Viral: HIV, Herpes and HPV (causes genital warts and cancer). These cannot be cured.\nSymptoms can be treated for viral but not cured.\nNONE of these are good\n\nWhat is Chlamydia?\nChlamydia Trachomatis (CT) is a bacterium whose natural host is humans and attacks their cells. The infection rate of chlamydial infections has increased steadily over the last 20 years in both men and women.\n\nHow is it Transmitted?\nThe mode of transmission is through an infected person to another is by sex.\nThis can be oral, vaginal, or anal sex \nChlamydia can also be passed onto a baby during birth, causing lung or eye infections. This is called neonatal chlamydia.\nDirect contact: This means infected genitalia touching for example the eye (few seconds to a minute is only how long this bacterium lasts outside a host). \n\nSo, if you have a vagina these are the Signs & Symptoms that can be experienced? \nBurning or pain when urinating.\nPain or bleeding after sex\nUnusual vaginal discharge.\nUnusual bleeding or spotting between periods\nPain in lower belly\nIf left untreated in females it can cause:\nInfertility\nPelvic inflammatory disease\nChronic pelvic pain\nAn increased risk of complications in pregnancy such as premature labour.\nFor those with a penis these are the signs & symptoms.\nUnusual discharge from penis\nPain when urinating\nSwollen and sore testicles\nIf left untreated in males it can cause:\nInfertility\n\nTreatment\nPrescription of antibiotics for you and your partners\nUsually cured in one dose\nGet another test after 3 months \nYour sexual partner(s) need to be notified and tested to reduce the chance of re-infection\n\nPrevention:\nStop transmission from one to the other.\nSex \u2013 use condoms, reduces direct contact.\nDental dams for oral sex.\nCheck all pregnant women for chlamydia and gonorrhoea as 70% of women have no symptoms. \nRegular check-ups with your doctor or sexual health clinic\n\n\nReferences\n\nhttps://www.qut.edu.au/news?id=152588\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NDXHVKOg8BQ\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dfd0l10gPPY\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dfd0l10gPPY\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O7oPgnHJtnM\nhttps://www1.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/75F30C0D2C126CAECA2583940015EDE3/$File/australia%E2%80%99s_notifiable_disease_status,_2015_annual_report_of_the_nndss.pdf\nChan, P. Atua principalmente nos seguintes temas: biotecnologia ambiental, nanotoxicologia, nanomedicina, sa\u00fade ambiental, biomonitoramento, ecotoxicologia, genotoxicidade, mutag\u00eanese e respostas de m\u00faltiplos biomarcadores em organismos aqu\u00e1ticos.\n\nCurr\u00edculo Lattes: http://lattes.cnpq.br/6325937100056775\n\nRefer\u00eancias Bibliogr\u00e1ficas:\n\nToxicity of engineered nanomaterials to aquatic and land snails: A scientometric and systematic review. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.chemosphere.2020.127654\n\nRisk assessment of iron oxide nanoparticles in an aquatic ecosystem: A case study on Biomphalaria glabrata. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jhazmat.2020.123398\n\nPEREIRA, ARYELLE CANEDO; GOMES, T\u00c2NIA; FERREIRA MACHADO, M\u00d4NICA RODRIGUES; ROCHA, THIAGO LOPES. This video also provides information of a freely downloadable clustering software called GenClust++.\n\n\n** Islam, M. Z., Estivill-Castro, V., Rahman, M. A. and Bossomaier, T. (2018): Combining K-Means and a Genetic Algorithm through a Novel Arrangement of Genetic Operators for High Quality Clustering, Expert Systems with Applications (ESWA), Vol. 91, pg. 402-417\n\n\nPreprint of the paper is available at: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/319524209\n\n\n\n** Beg, A. H., Islam, M. Z., and Estivill-Castro. V. (2016): Genetic Algorithm with Healthy Population and Multiple Streams Sharing Information for Clustering, Knowledge-Based Systems, Vol. 114, pp. 61-78, ISSN 0219-1377, Springer London. doi: http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.knosys.2016.09.030 \n\n\n\nPreprint of the paper is available at: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/309275811\n\n\n\n** Rahman, M. A., and Islam, M. Z. (2014): A Hybrid Clustering Technique Combining a Novel Genetic Algorithm with K-Means, Knowledge-Based Systems, Vol. 71, November 2014, pp. 345-365, DOI: 10.1016/j.knosys.2014.08.011\n\n\nPriprint of the paper is available at: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/264623472\n\n\n** Beg, A. H., Islam, M. Z., and Estivill-Castro, V. (2020): HeMI++: A Genetic Algorithm based Clustering Technique for Sensible Clusters, In Proc. of the IEEE Congress on Evolutionary Computation (IEEE CEC 2020), Glasgow, UK, July 19-24, 2020\n\n\nPreprint of the paper is available at: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/341118082", "channelId": "UCrcz90CHdK6GrtnMvk_vVXA", "publishedAt": "2020-06-28T09:18:07Z", "channelTitle": "Zahid's Data Mining Channel"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "3", "viewCount": "52", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "1", "commentCount": "3"}, "id": "JYLB9p5ZjTk", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT9M51S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.eswa.2016.09.030", "q": "10.1016/j.eswa.2016.09.030"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"defaultLanguage": "id", "channelId": "UC2cEwH60KW-UC17SyqpEatQ", "title": "High-slope terrain locomotion for torque-controlled quadruped robots (AURO'17)", "description": "High-slope terrain locomotion for torque-controlled quadruped robots\n\nM. Focchi, A. del Prete, I. Havoutis, R. Featherstone, D. G. Caldwell, C. Semini\n\nAutonomous Robots 2017\n\nAbstract\u2014 Research into legged robotics is primarily motivated by the prospects of building machines that are able to navigate in challenging and complex environments that are predominantly  non-flat. In this context, control of contact forces is fundamental to ensure stable contacts and equilibrium of the robot. In this paper we propose a planning/control framework for quasi-static walking of quadrupedal robots, implemented for a demanding application in which regulation of ground reaction forces is crucial. Experimental results demonstrate that our 75kg quadruped robot is able to walk inside two high-slope (50\u25e6) V-shaped walls; an achieve ment that to the authors\u2019 best knowledge has never been presented  before. The  robot distributes its weight among the stance legs so as to optimize user-defined criteria. We compute joint torques that result in no foot slippage, fulfillment of the unilateral constraints of the contact forces and minimization of the actuators effort. The presented study is an experimental validation of the effectiveness and robustness\nof QP-based force distributions methods for quasi-static locomotion on challenging terrain.\n\nOfficial paper download link at publisher: http://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10514-016-9573-1\n\nPre-prints of all our papers can be found here: http://www.iit.it/hyq (Publications)\n\nThe following publications provide the details about the whole-body controller:\n\nM. Focchi, A. del Prete, I. Havoutis, R. Featherstone, D. G. Caldwell, C. Semini, High-slope terrain locomotion for torque-controlled quadruped robots, Autonomous Robots, 259-272, 2017.", "channelTitle": "Dynamic Legged Systems lab", "publishedAt": "2017-04-12T14:26:50Z"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "11", "viewCount": "1338", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "commentCount": "1"}, "id": "-qQp2RwQ-PQ", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT5M6S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1007/s10514-016-9573-1", "q": "10.1007/s10514-016-9573-1"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"title": "Goal-directed Robot Manipulation by Axiomatic Particle Filtering", "description": "Paper Link: http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/0278364916683444\n\nAbstract:\nPerforming robust goal-directed manipulation tasks remains a crucial challenge for autonomous robots. In an ideal case, shared autonomous control of manipulators would allow human users to specify their intent as a goal state and have the robot reason over the actions and motions to achieve this goal. However, realizing this goal remains elusive due to the problem of perceiving the robot\u2019s environment. We address and describe the problem of axiomatic scene estimation for robot manipulation in cluttered scenes which is the estimation of a tree-structured scene graph describing the configuration of objects observed from robot sensing. We propose generative approaches to scene inference (as the axiomatic particle filter, and the axiomatic scene estimation by Markov chain Monte Carlo based sampler) of the robot\u2019s environment as a scene graph. The result from AxScEs estimation are axioms amenable to goal-directed manipulation through symbolic inference for task planning and collision-free motion planning and execution. We demonstrate the results for goal-directed manipulation of multi-object scenes by a PR2 robot.\n\n\nBibtex:\n@article{Suietal2017ijrr,\n  title={Goal-directed robot manipulation through axiomatic scene estimation},\n  author={Sui, Zhiqiang and Xiang, Lingzhu and Jenkins, Odest C and Desingh, Karthik},\n  journal={The International Journal of Robotics Research},\n  volume={36},\n  number={1},\n  pages={86--104},\n  year={2017},\n  publisher={SAGE Publications Sage UK: London, England}\n}", "channelId": "UCg0KqGxmJNqmtaKFNDlmzzw", "publishedAt": "2017-03-17T01:13:56Z", "channelTitle": "Zhiqiang Sui"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "3", "viewCount": "474", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "uD3VkaC5R8M", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT3M41S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1177/0278364916683444", "q": "10.1177/0278364916683444"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"tags": ["HMD", "HTC VIVE", "CAVE2", "IMMERSIVE", "VISUALISATION", "NETWORK", "GRAPH", "ABSTRACT VISUALISATION", "COLLABORATIVE VISUALISATION", "INFOVIS", "INFOVIS16"], "channelId": "UCFCe67M8Jq3wSHQjqNJDFvg", "title": "Immersive and Collaborative Visualisation of 3D networks: CAVE2 or Oculus Rift?", "description": "Video fast forward of the INFOVIS16 paper \"Immersive Collaborative Analysis of Network Connectivity: CAVE-style or Head-Mounted Display?\"\nAuthors:  Maxime Cordeil ;  Tim Dwyer ;  Karsten Klein ;  Bireswar Laha ;  Kim Marriott ;  Bruce H. The software allows a robust control and adaptive binocular coordination for different robot stereo platforms.\n\nThe software is publicly released by the authors at: https://sourceforge.net/projects/robotics-vergence-control/\n\nThe Vergence Control working on a real robot stereo head (iCub) can be seen here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fD73I-HJL04\n\n\nThe details about theory, implementation and effectiveness of the Vergence Control are published in this paper:\nGibaldi, A., Vanegas, M., Canessa, A., & Sabatini, S. P. (2017). A portable bio-inspired architecture for efficient robotic vergence control. International Journal of Computer Vision, 121(2), 281-302.\nhttps://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11263-016-0936-z\n\nVideo description:\n- the DEMO 1 shows the Vergence Control elaborating a 540 x 960 pixel image, 20 times in a for loop, and shows the computational time and the achieved FPS.\n- the DEMO 2 elaborates a stereo image shown in anaglyph mode.\nThe mouse is used to select the desired fixation point in the image, and the algorithm computes the required control to correctly verge at fixation. Vergence eye movements are simulated warping the stereo image, and the correct vergence is reached when the left and right images become equal at \u00a0fixation, i.e. when the anaglyph turns int gray scale.\n\nFor further information or support, please contact the author at agostino.gibaldi@gmail.com", "channelTitle": "AgostinoGibaldi", "publishedAt": "2018-02-09T09:04:53Z"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "1", "viewCount": "274", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "k6yDMyht184", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1M12S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1007/s11263-016-0936-z", "q": "10.1007/s11263-016-0936-z"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"tags": ["SciShow", "science", "Hank", "Green", "education", "learn", "baculum", "mammals", "baubellum", "primates", "behavior", "bone", "ovulation", "oocytes", "egg cells", "prolonged intromission", "monogamy", "anatomy", "physiology"], "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "defaultLanguage": "en", "channelId": "UCZYTClx2T1of7BRZ86-8fow", "title": "Why Don\u2019t Humans Have Penis Bones?", "description": "Most other mammals have penis bones, so why don't we?\n\nHosted by: Michael Aranda\n----------\nSupport SciShow by becoming a patron on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/scishow\n----------\nDooblydoo thanks go to the following Patreon supporters: Kelly Landrum Jones, Sam Lutfi, Kevin Knupp, Nicholas Smith, D.A. Patrick McLaughlin MD is a Professor of Radiation Oncology at the University of Michigan. He is the Director of Radiation Oncology at the Providence Affiliate of the University of Michigan. He completed a medical oncology fellowship at the University of Michigan, immediately migrating to radiation oncology. He is board certified in medical and radiation oncology.\n\nHis major research interest is in technical advances in prostate cancer radiation (internal and external). This work culminated in the development of vessel sparing radiation, the radiation equivalent to nerve sparing surgery. This model includes refinements to the Neo Tethys where East Java-West Sulawesi blocks from the Argo Abyssal Plain are transferred on the NW Australian shelf towards Sundaland, also including refinement to the evolution of the Kohistan-Ladakh, Woyla, and Philippine intra-oceanic arcs, in the context of the evolving Sundaland and New Guinea continental margins. Plate boundaries are depicted, which include Subduction Zones (Pink Lines) and MOR/Transforms (Black Lines). The blue, yellow, orange and red regions portray the plate velocities from slowest (0 cm/yr) to fastest (30 cm/yr) respectively. The black arrows represent the plate velocity vectors. Orthographic reconstructions are centred on 115\u00b0E, 15\u00b0S.\n\nSupplementary Material:\nhttps://www.earthbyte.org/webdav/ftp/Data_Collections/Zahirovic_etal_ESR_EasternTethys_Supplement.zip \n\nReference:\nZahirovic, S., K.J. This model includes refinements to the Neo-Tethys where East Java-West Sulawesi blocks from the Argo Abyssal Plain are transferred from the NW Australian shelf towards Sundaland, also including refinement to the evolution of the Kohistan-Ladakh, Woyla, and Philippine intra-oceanic arcs, in the context of the evolving Sundaland and New Guinea continental margins. The animation shows large-scale mantle evolution in the latest Jurassic and Early Cretaceous from Tethyan subduction along Lhasa and the Kohistan-Ladakh Arc, as well as recycling of proto-Pacific lithosphere along the East Asian, East Gondwana and Philippine Arc subduction zones. Plate boundaries (white), velocities (coloured arrows) and reconstructed present-day coastlines (translucent white) are plotted. Subduction zones are yellow regions, and slab colouring is a function of depth from light blue (shallow slabs) to darker blue (deep slabs). Central co-ordinate is 10\u00b0S, 115\u00b0E. The cross-section depicts the temperature field from the numerical mantle flow models, and the globes show the position of the vertical slices through time, the plate reconstruction and the predicted mantle temperature field at ~400 km depth. The background mantle temperature is ~1413\u00b0C, and the small tick marks on the temperature scale represent temperature intervals of 250\u00b0C. Great circle angular distance along the vertical profile is shown on the x-axis. The left y-axis represents depth in kilometres, and on the right represents non-dimensional Earth radius. The southernmost slab is related to the subduction of the Sepik oceanic gateway (SEP) between ~71 and 30 Ma, while Maramuni subduction (MS) has taken place since ~20 Ma, coeval with north-dipping subduction along the Halmahera Arc to produce the Caroline/Proto Molucca slab. The cross-sections depict the temperature field from the numerical mantle flow models, and the globes show the position of the vertical slices through time, the plate reconstruction and the predicted mantle temperature field at ~400 km depth. The background mantle temperature is ~1413\u00b0C, and the small tick marks on the temperature scale represent temperature intervals of 250\u00b0C. Great circle angular distance along the vertical profile is shown on the x-axis. The left y-axis represents depth in kilometres, and on the right represents non-dimensional Earth radius. More details about the MIT-Haiti Initiative can be found at http://haiti.mit.edu .", "channelTitle": "Michel DeGraff", "publishedAt": "2015-04-17T02:13:15Z"}, "statistics": {"viewCount": "1089", "favoriteCount": "0"}, "id": "PSqUnOwmYH0", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT12M44S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2016.09.005", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2016.09.005"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelId": "UCMGZJqD9_Xzhix-je4oK7Hw", "title": "Hard and soft allopatry: modes of geographic speciation of the yellow-bellied kingsnake in...", "description": "**Seminar in Zoology II**\n\nTitle: Hard and soft allopatry: modes of geographic speciation of the yellow-bellied kingsnake in North America\n\nMiss Damisa Kaminsin ID: 6270137823\nAdvisor: Asst. Prof. Dr. Amporn Wiwegweaw\n\nAbstract\nThe Mississippi River is recognized as an important geographic barrier to gene flow and generates species in North America. The yellow-bellied kingsnake, Lampropeltis calligaster, is widely distributed in several areas in North America. It consists of three subspecies: L. c. calligaster, L. c. rhombomaculata and L. c. occipitolineata, which differ morphologically and geographically (distinct ecological niches). The former two subspecies are primarily found in western (grasslands) and eastern (forests) sides of the Mississippi River regions, respectively, and they were historically isolated by this river, while the third is restricted to South Florida peninsular. In this study, the researchers utilized phylogeographic analyses to examine timing and mode of speciation and causes of current lineage diversification in the L. calligaster complex. Gene trees constructed by mtDNA (Cytochrome b) and nDNA (CLLAT, NT3, PRLR and VIM56 loci) sequences demonstrated that 98% of individuals were clearly grouped into 3 lineages: western, eastern and South Florida lineages. Divergence dating and historical demography analyses revealed that three subspecies originated during the Pleistocene epoch, followed by range expansion and increasing population size over the last 100,000 years. Additionally, the result from a Mantel test showed that the pattern of lineage diversification is strongly associated with ecological divergence occurred on each side of the river. This result supports the hypothesis that ecological transition due to climate change during the Pleistocene is a causal factor driving L. calligaster diversification. Migrate tests detected symmetric gene flow with equal rate of migration between eastern and western populations, indicating that speciation and current diversification in this species groups is likely due to the effect of ecological transition rather than historical riverine vicariance. Moreover, ecological niche modeling predicted that the future ranges of eastern and South Florida kingsnake may be decreased due to urbanization and climate change. This prediction provides preliminary information to assist conservation planning and management for L. calligaster. in the future. \n\nReferences:\nMcKelvy, A.D., Burbrink, F.T. 2017. Ecological divergence in the yellow-bellied kingsnake (Lampropeltis calligaster) at two North American biodiversity hotspots. Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution. 106: 61\u201372.\nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.ympev.2016.09.006\n\nPyron, R.A., Burbrink, F.T. 2010. Hard and soft allopatry: physically and ecologically mediated modes of geographic speciation. Occupations humaines du Pal\u00e9olithique dans les Abruzzes", "description": "\u00a9 Projet de l'\u00c9cole fran\u00e7aise de Rome en collaboration avec la Soprintendenza per i beni archeologici dell\u2019Abruzzo\n\nFilm r\u00e9alis\u00e9 par Laura Haby et Pierre Gaignard\nSeptembre 2015\nProduction : Ecole fran\u00e7aise de Rome\nConseil scientifique : Elisa Nicoud\n\nValle Giumentina est un site arch\u00e9ologique du Pl\u00e9istoc\u00e8ne moyen d\u2019Italie centrale (MIS 15-12 ; 580 000 - 420 000 ans). La fouille s\u2019int\u00e8gre au projet quinquennal de l\u2019\u00c9cole fran\u00e7aise de Rome sur le Pal\u00e9olithique d'Italie centrale. Elle regroupe une \u00e9quipe de recherche multidisciplinaire et franco-italienne.\nValle Giumentina est une petite vall\u00e9e suspendue \u00e0 pr\u00e8s de 740 m d\u2019altitude, occup\u00e9e par un lac au Pl\u00e9istoc\u00e8ne moyen. Dans les s\u00e9diments lacustres \u00e9pais de 70 m, onze niveaux arch\u00e9ologiques sont apparus en contexte de pal\u00e9osols (fouilles Radmilli et Demangeot, 1953-54) dans les 25 m\u00e8tres sup\u00e9rieurs. Ils contiennent des industries lithiques attribu\u00e9es \u00e0 des groupes humains n\u00e9andertaliens (\u00ab Clactonien \u00bb, \u00ab Acheul\u00e9en \u00bb, \"Moust\u00e9rien\"). Depuis 2012, la fouille a pris place sur 51 m\u00b2 dans les niveaux sup\u00e9rieurs. Un carottage m\u00e9canique de 45 m, des pr\u00e9l\u00e8vements sur la coupe de 17 m de hauteur et des profils g\u00e9ophysiques de la vall\u00e9e ont \u00e9t\u00e9 r\u00e9alis\u00e9s. \n\nResponsables de la fouille (2012-2016) : Elisa Nicoud, Daniele Aureli et Marina Pagli.\n\nInstitutions partenaires :\n\u00c9cole fran\u00e7aise de Rome, Soprintendenza per i beni archeologici dell\u2019Abruzzo, INRAP, ArScAn-AnTeT (UMR 7041), Universit\u00e0 degli studi di Siena (preistoria e antropologia), di Pisa (biologia), di Firenze (scienze della Terra), di Roma La Sapienza, Universit\u00e9 Paris 1 Panth\u00e9on-Sorbonne (ED de g\u00e9ographie de Paris), Universit\u00e9 Bordeaux 3, CNR, CNRS (CEPAM UMR 7264, LGP UMR 8591, ASM UMR 5140, IRAMAT UMR 5060, LSCE UMR 8212 et HNHP UMR 7194), Max Planck Institute for Evolutionary Anthropology, Mus\u00e9um national d\u2019Histoire naturelle, Commissariat \u00e0 l\u2019\u00e9nergie atomique, Fondation Pescarabruzzo, Parco nazionale della Majella, Comune di Abbateggio, Comune di Caramanico Terme, Museo delle Genti d\u2019Abruzzo, Archeoclub di Pescara.\n\nPour en savoir plus :\nhttps://www.cepam.cnrs.fr/projets/operations-archeologiques-de-terrain/operation-valle-giumentina-italie-paleolithique-inferieur/\n\nhttps://journals.openedition.org/cefr/4206\nhttps://journals.openedition.org/cefr/2713\nhttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.quascirev.2018.01.014\nhttp://journals.openedition.org/cefr/1891\nhttp://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.quascirev.2016.11.029\nhttp://cefr.revues.org/1656\nhttp://amq.aiqua.it/images/joomd/AMQ2927Villa193-199.pdf\nhttp://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.quascirev.2016.09.006\nhttps://afeq.hypotheses.org/1626\nhttp://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.quaint.2015.08.080\nhttp://cefr.revues.org/1507\nhttps://cefr.revues.org/1306\nhttp://mefra.revues.org/2659\nhttp://mefra.revues.org/2658\nhttps://cefr.revues.org/1081\nhttps://cefr.revues.org/902", "channelId": "UCTLSXue6DXl8F8INUJFvB5Q", "publishedAt": "2020-07-06T15:21:40Z", "channelTitle": "CEPAM CNRS - Volvulus is a common etiology of intestinal obstruction and is often due to malrotation in utero.  &nbsp;\r\n\r\n Editor\u2019s note: get an upper GI series if there is any bilious vomiting in a neonate. Any time of the night. Wake people up. Transfer if necessary to get the study. This can diagnose volvulus and save bowel.\r\n\r\n References:\r\n\r\n Ratnayake K, Kim TY. Rj BROOKE & 26.7.2020. doi.org/10.1016/j.shpsc.2016.09.004", "description": "https://www.newsarawaktribune.com.my/brooke-world-heritage-site/\n\n One of Sarawak\u2019s most famous historical sites is located around the riverine bazaar of Siniawan and Mount Serembu. It is the enclave of an old Chinese settlement going back 200 years amidst the Bidayuh community who built their longhouses around the 1,646ft high Gunung Serembu mountain complex at Bung Muan. Siniawan was made famous by Rajah James Brooke who built a cottage high up in the hills, and within 30 years had attracted world-famous 19th century personalities to Sarawak.\nSir Hugh Low became the first European to travel to Upper Sarawak to explore the region.\nOthers who visited Rajah James Brooke\u2019s Mountain eyrie which received International acclaim were Governor-General of Labuan Sir Spenser Buckingham St John and author of \u201cLife in the Forests in the Far East\u201d.\nAustrian author Madam Ida Laura Pfeiffer, Italian naturalist Odoardo Beccari, British admiral Sir Henry Keppel and world-renowned Alfred Russel Wallace, who was described as one of the greatest scientists of all time. His paper was jointly published with some of Charles Darwin\u2019s writings of the \u201cEvolution of Man\u201d in 1858.\nJames Brooke first travelled up the Sarawak River in 1839 to quell a rebellion led by the Sarawak Malay chief Datu Patinggi Ali who had challenged the authority of the Brunei Sultanate who had colonised the State from as early as the 15th century.\nIn 184, Brooke became their Rajah and their Bidayuh allies at Bung Muan. He also extended the protection of the British navy to the region.\nOn July 15, 1843 a young mid shipman, artist-cum-author Frank Marryat from H.M.S. Samarang was sent on an expedition to the antimony and gold mines in Bau when he wrote:\n\u201cA short distance inland is a mountain, called Sarambo (Serembu), which it was proposed to ascend, as, by our telescopes, we could perceive houses near to its summit and were told it was the residence of some of the mountain Dayaks under Mr Brooke\u2019s sway.\u201d\nWhat Marryat saw was \u201cBung Muan\u201d where a cluster of three villages \u2014 Penijau, Bumbok and Serembu Bidayuh longhouses community.\nThe Bidayuh had chosen to live 1,000 feet high up in the mountains to protect themselves from raids by Sea Dayak pirates during the reign of the Brunei sultanate.\nIn one raid alone in 1838, the \u201cheadhunters\u201d from Skrang and Saribas had pillaged a neighbouring longhouse community several miles upriver at Bung Bratak, killing hundreds and taking many slaves.\nBrooke put an end to head-hunting and built a cottage just above Bung Muan at place called \u201cPeninjau\u201d.\nSpenser St John said Peninjau got its name from a large rock jutting out of mountain from where the Rajah would sit enjoy a panoramic view of Gunung Santubong and the meandering Sarawak River.\nIn November 1854, Brooke met Alfred Wallace in Singapore and invited him to enjoy at his idyllic cottage where the latter spent four months.\nWallace returned to Peninjau in December 1855, with a Malay boy called Ali which by that time it had been developed into a quaint cottage and describes it as a rude wooden lodge where a cool spring under an overhanging rock.\nItalian naturalist Beccari who stayed at Peninjau in 1865 said Brooke\u2019s bungalow was 300 feet above the longhouses at Bung Muan which was describes as \u201ca place with an extensive view\u201d. Beccari in \u201cWanderings in the Great Forests of Borneo\u201d (1865) said a \u201cstream gushed out of a great cave where the rajah\u2019s men would wash and bathe.\u201d\nAfter James Brooke\u2019s demise in 1868, and with his nephew Charles at the helm, \u201cPeninjau\u201d fell into disrepair.\nIn 1912, J.C. Moulton, spent a fortnight at Serembu using the longer but flatter \u201cWestern Paku-Merembeh Route\u201d as a homage to Wallace. Accompanied by American Harrison W Smith who took photographs, they noted there were just remnants of the \u201cbelian\u201d (ironwood) posts left from the Rajah\u2019s time. Sir James Brooke had a bungalow which they helped to build\u201d.\nBrook paid the Peninjau Dayaks one \u201cBedil\u201d (small cannon) as the fee to build his bungalow. Moulton and Smith returned to Kuching using the Peninjau side to Siniawan, which was shorter route home but with a more difficult descent down the steep mountain.\nRajah Brooke\u2019s cottage at \u201cPeninjau\u201d which in Malay means \u201cthe lookout\u201d, remained forgotten until the 1980s when an English Earl Lord Cranbrook, took an interest in this famous location where Wallace had carried out his studies on the Orang Utan. Between 1854 and 1962 Wallace collected an estimated 5,000 new species (mostly animals) during his eight-year tour of the \u2018Malay Archipelago\u2019.\nIt was Wallace who \u2018discovered\u2019 a rare Sarawak\u2019s two-clubbed spider (Friula wallacei) which has been preserved in the Oxford Museum of Natural History in UK. Wallace told a friend that he caught the spider in Sarawak and specially noted its remarkable form.\nA former University of Malaya lecturer who first arrived in Sarawak in 1956, Cranbrook said, \u201cI had been looking for Bung Muan for a long time.", "channelTitle": "Taj Abdullah", "publishedAt": "2020-07-26T14:38:06Z"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "4", "viewCount": "15", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "commentCount": "1"}, "id": "4MWvD3kzxH8", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT11M42S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2016.09.004", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2016.09.004"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"title": "PhD graduation ceremony at University of Technology, Sydney", "description": "This is a graduation ceremony for a doctoral degree at University of Technology, Sydney (UTS).
