The top panel shows a 1000 nanosecond simulation of the antibiotic peptide alamethicin in DOPC (1,2-dioleoyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphocholine), and the bottom panel shows the antimicrobial peptide piscidin 1 in 3:1 POPC/POPG (1-palmitoyl-2-oleoyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphocholine/1-palmitoyl-2-oleoyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphoglycerol). Peptides are shown as orange (hydrophobic residues) and green (polar and charged residues) ribbons, water molecules are shown as light gray spheres, and the lipid phosphorus are dark gray spheres. The rest of the lipids are omitted for clarity (the empty white band is the hydrophobic interior of the membrane).\n\nThe primary result is that alamethicin is unstable on the membrane surface, buries itself into the membrane, and folds into a helix; while the piscidin 1 helix is optimized for binding the water-membrane interface. Hence, 10 alamethicin peptide begin on the surface and insert in 1000 ns, and the 10 piscidin peptides remain surface-bound. After 300 ns, the simulation skips to 950 ns. \n\nSimulations were performed at 413K with a -200mV electric field. Details can be found in Perrin and Pastor BJ 2016 ( http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.bpj.2016.08.014 ) and Perrin, Fu, Cotten, and Pastor BJ 2016 ( http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.bpj.2016.08.015 ).", "channelTitle": "PerrinResearch", "publishedAt": "2016-11-16T04:12:29Z"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "viewCount": "238", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "S7M747F7Nkc", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1M"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2016.08.014", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2016.08.014"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"tags": ["Molecular Dynamics", "Membrane Biophysics", "Antimicrobial Peptides", "Membrane Active Peptides", "Barrel-Stave Pores", "Peptide Pores"], "channelId": "UCmddLgtqQwQGuErWrjHGRtQ", "title": "All-atom MD simulations of Alamethicin and Piscidin Pores", "description": "All-atom molecular dynamics simulations of two peptides starting from barrel-stave pore conformations.\n\nLeft) A 14.1 microsecond trajectory of the antibiotic peptide alamethicin in DOPC (1,2-dioleoyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphocholine). Alamethicin peptides are shown as orange (hydrophobic residues) and green (polar and charged residues) ribbons, water molecules are distinguished as in the pore (cyan spheres) or non-pore (light gray spheres), and the lipid phosphorus are dark gray spheres. The rest of the lipids are omitted for clarity (the empty white band is the hydrophobic interior of the membrane). \n\nRight) A 20 (of 26) microsecond trajectory of the antimicrobial peptide piscidin 1 in 3:1 POPC/POPG (1-palmitoyl-2-oleoyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphocholine/1-palmitoyl-2-oleoyl-sn-glycero-3-phosphoglycerol). This movie focuses on one of four pores in the simulation. The pore  Peptides that started in this pores are orange, those from neighboring pores are purple. Water molecules are distinguished as in the pore (cyan spheres) or out of the pore (light gray spheres). Gray spheres are POPC phosphorus atoms and green sphere are POPG phosphorus atoms. The rest of the lipids are omitted for clarity.\n\nThe primary result is that the alamethicin peptides remain as a stable peptide pore for the entire 14 microseconds. In contrast, the piscidin pores quickly become disordered and incorporate lipids between the peptides. The pore collapses and all of its peptides are surface-bound by 15.2 microseconds.\n\nDetails can be found in Perrin and Pastor BJ 2016 ( http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.bpj.2016.08.014 ) and Perrin, Fu, (2016) published in Cell, http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cell.2016.08.006\n \nWritten and narrated by Shamba Saha. Edited and produced by Lisa Dennison.\n\nSee the post on sciencesketches.org for more: http://www.sciencesketches.org/single-post/2016/09/15/How-do-cells-position-liquid-droplets\n\nThis video first appeared in the \"Two Minute Talk\" series of Tony Hyman's lab.", "channelTitle": "ScienceSketches", "publishedAt": "2016-09-16T15:36:33Z"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "4", "viewCount": "233", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "sQznKsCVFJ8", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M16S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2016.08.006", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2016.08.006"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"tags": ["robot coordination", "spot welding", "cell desing", "cell configuration", "industrial robotics"], "channelId": "UCBVtG5XI4R2LC_y1WAD8s8g", "title": "Multi robot coordination and cell design", "description": "Multi-robot cells for spot welding use coordinated robots to assemble metal panels via spot welding by coordinated robots, for instance in the construction of car doors. The design of multi-robot cells for spot welding required both cell design and off-line motion planning. Cell design involves resource selection  (such as robots and welding guns) and resource configuration, while considering cell productivity, costs, flexibility and reconfigurability. Motion planning involves allocating welding points to each resource and calculating collision-free motion plan for each robot. Currently, cell design and motion planning are sequential and manual activities, managed by different and separate industrial functional units. This results in several cycles before the design converges to a feasible final solution. The proposed approach introduces a unified methodology, aiming at optimizing the holistic cell design and motion planning, that reduces design time and errors. The feasibility of the proposed approach has been demonstrated in several ad-hoc basic replicable cases and in one industrial case. The outcome of this research improves state of the art, reducing design and motion planning time over current technology. Moreover, the method has been integrated into a computerized approach which has the potential to accelerate the whole cell design and motion planning processes and to reduce human efforts.\nhttp://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.rcim.2016.08.006", "channelTitle": "Intelligent Robots and Autonomous Systems", "publishedAt": "2016-08-26T09:13:41Z"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "2", "viewCount": "282", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "E0kjbobwgBY", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT3M32S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2016.08.006", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2016.08.006"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"tags": ["optimism", "positive thinking", "FIU", "evidence base", "evolution", "controversy"], "channelId": "UCgmWpzR0ah5tTQ09xwD3FNA", "title": "Understanding optimism", "description": "Reference\n\n\nEngberg, Henriette, Bernard Jeune, Karen Andersen-Ranberg, Torben Martinussen, James W. The Cardiovascular Risk in Young Finns Study.\"\u00a0Journal of Psychosomatic Research\u00a0100 (2017): 61-64. doi:10.1016/j.jpsychores.2017.07.006.", "channelTitle": "Yeiniel Rodriguez", "publishedAt": "2018-04-15T00:44:57Z"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "2", "viewCount": "77", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "rX_XP5z22wE", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT8M5S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2016.08.006", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2016.08.006"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"tags": ["Wi-Fi", "schools", "EMR", "radiation", "wireless", "EMFs", "children", "parents", "teachers"], "channelId": "UCzuZvoQ3sNSGyEZWf4SYf8w", "title": "Why Wi-Fi Should Be Out of Schools and Homes - Dr Pri Bandara - 7 of 9", "description": "Dr. Priyanka (Pri) Bandara is an independent researcher and educator in environmental health. As a former academic clinical and basic researcher (Westmead and Royal Prince Alfred Hospitals as well as Medicine at University of Sydney and UNSW) she gained experience in hepatology, biochemistry and molecular genetics and molecular pharmacology. Dr. Bandara also served as a senior manager in the NSW health system coordinating a dynamic research team and a clinical team at Westmead Children\u2019s Hospital (Neurogenetics Research Unit and the Institute for Neuroscience & Muscular Research). She subsequently became involved in environment health realizing the greater need to focus on prevention of chronic diseases rather than on intervention.\nShe studied genetic regulation of cellular oxidative stress responses for her doctoral studies at UNSW in the late 1990s and has continued her interest in this area - pathologically involved in almost every disease. Investigating cytotoxic effects of various environmental pollutants via complex cellular pathways, she furthers the understanding of the health impact of our changing world.\nDr. Bandara has a keen interest in the biological/ health effects of currently permitted \u201clow levels\u201d of microwave radiofrequency electromagnetic radiation (RF-EMR) widely generated for mobile and wireless communication and surveillance technologies and released into the environment. Despite being heavily marketed, these technologies have not been subjected to adequate safety testing and the current regulation is entirely based on short-term heating effects. Dr. Bandara collaborates with a large group of scientists and clinicians around the world who are trying to educate health authorities and the public about safer use of wireless tech, bring about more protective exposure guidelines for man-made electromagnetic radiation (www.emfscientist.org ). She is a strong advocate for stringent control of environmental toxicants, including \u201cwireless radiation\u201d (RF-EMR) to mainly safeguard more vulnerable children.\nCutting-edge research demonstrates that oxidative stress is a key mechanism by which RF-EMR exerts detrimental effects on living cells, including damage to vital genetic material DNA. Translating complex science into simple lay terms and explaining the findings of credible research studies, Dr. Bandara empower people them with knowledge required for protection of health in 21st century.\nDr. Bandara has published in international peer-reviewed scientific journals and presented at major conferences and leading Australian academic institutions. She is an executive member of the Oceania Radiofrequency Scientific Advisory Association (ORSAA) http://www.orsaa.org/ and a member of the scientific advisory boards of the Environmental Health Trust USA (http://ehtrust.org). She can be contacted via: pri.bandara@orsaa.org\nDr. Bandara\u2019s scientific publications in the area of health effects of electromagnetic radiation:\n\u2022 Bandara P and Carpenter DO. Planetary Electromagnetic Pollution: It is Time to Assess its Impact. Lancet Planetary Health 2018 Dec. DOI:https://doi.org/10.1016/S2542-5196(18)30221-3\n\u2022 Bandara P, Weller S and Leach V. Health Risks of Wireless Technologies. Radiation Protection In Australasia (journal of the Australasian Radiation Protection Society), 2018 Nov; 35(2): 22-26.\n\u2022 Bandara P and Weller S. Cardiovascular disease: Time to identify emerging environmental risk factors (Invited Editorial). European Journal of Preventive Cardiology, 2017 Nov; 24(17):1819-1823. doi: 10.1177/2047487317734898. Epub 2017 Oct 3.\n\u2022 Bandara P and Weller S. Biological effects of low-intensity radiofrequency electromagnetic radiation \u2013 time for a paradigm shift in regulation of public exposure. Radiation Protection In Australasia, 2017 Nov; 34(2): 2-9.\n\u2022 Bandara P and Johansson O. Letter to the Editor (Rebuttal of WiFi in Australian Schools by ARPANSA) Radiation Protection Dosimetry. 2018 Feb 1;178(3):288-291. doi: 10.1093/rpd/ncx108.\n\u2022 Bandara P. Mobile phone use and the brain cancer incidence rate in Australia. Cancer Epidemiology, 2016 Oct; 44:110-111. doi: 10.1016/j.canep.2016.08.006. Epub 2016 Aug 20.\n\u2022 Bandara P. Impaired Public Health in the Wireless Age. ACNEM Journal (Journal of the Australasian College of Nutritional and Environmental Medicine), 2014 Sept; 33(2);3-9\n\u2022 Bandara P and Weller S. Oxidative Stress is Caused by Currently Permitted Levels of Radiofrequency Electromagnetic Radiation for Wireless Communications \u2013 a Systematic Review (in preparation)\n\u2022 Bandara P, Carpenter DO and Sasco A. Mythical and Actual Causes of Cancer \u2013 What does the Scientific Evidence Show? (in preparation).", "channelTitle": "ZIPPS media", "publishedAt": "2019-09-23T22:16:35Z"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "11", "viewCount": "231", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "commentCount": "2"}, "id": "765ceZMl3OQ", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT18M53S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2016.08.006", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2016.08.006"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"tags": ["motion planning", "industrial robots", "cell design", "spot welding", "motion coordination", "robot coordination"], "channelId": "UCIfmHBhbPYZM_VX4SmeKSVw", "title": "Cell Design and Multi-robot coordination", "description": "Multi-robot cells for spot welding use coordinated robots to assemble metal panels via spot welding by coordinated robots, for instance in the construction of car doors. The design of multi-robot cells for spot welding required both cell design and off-line motion planning. Cell design involves resource selection  (such as robots and welding guns) and resource configuration, while considering cell productivity, costs, flexibility and reconfigurability. Motion planning involves allocating welding points to each resource and calculating collision-free motion plan for each robot. Currently, cell design and motion planning are sequential and manual activities, managed by different and separate industrial functional units. This results in several cycles before the design converges to a feasible final solution. The proposed approach introduces a unified methodology, aiming at optimizing the holistic cell design and motion planning, that reduces design time and errors. The feasibility of the proposed approach has been demonstrated in several ad-hoc basic replicable cases and in one industrial case. The outcome of this research improves state of the art, reducing design and motion planning time over current technology. Moreover, the method has been integrated into a computerized approach which has the potential to accelerate the whole cell design and motion planning processes and to reduce human efforts. Clinical practice guidelines for South African paramedics has recently been updated and is being implemented nationally, however implementation by industry and decision makers needs to be strengthened further.  To address this, researchers from Stellenbosch University have conducted studies to strengthen guideline uptake by identifying prehospital end-users\u2019 perceptions of the guidelines, including barriers and facilitators for national decision makers. "title": "A Game Changer for Concrete?? - Nano Scale Observations of Cement Hydration", "description": "Sometimes looking at something in a new way allows us to learn a lot about it.  This video uses X-ray nano computed tomography and X-ray nano fluorescence to examine the structure and chemical composition of early age hydration at the nano length scale.  This video examines the variability of hydration of individual particles.  Next, the experiments look at the pore structure within the hydrated cement paste and finally, the work tracks how individual particles change over the first few hours of hydration and makes important insights into how the hydration products change.  \n\nMore details can be found in:\n\nHu, Q., Aboustait, M., Kim, T., Ley, M.T., Bullard, J., Scherer, G., Hanan, J.C., Rose, V., Winarski, R., Gelb, J., \u201cDirect Measurements of Structure, Chemistry and Mass Density During the Induction Period of C3S Hydration\u201d, Cement and Concrete Research, 2016, doi:10.1016/j.cemconres.2016.07.008.\n\nHu, Q.,  Aboustait, M., Kim, T., Ley, M.T., Hanan, J.C., Bullard, J., Winarski, R., Rose, V., \u201cDirect three-dimensional observation of the microstructure and chemistry of C3S hydration\u201d, Cement and Concrete Research, 2016, doi:10.1016/j.cemconres.2016.07.006.\n\n\nBullard, J.W., Hagedorn, J.H., Ley, M.T., Hu, Q., Griffin, W., Terrill, J.E., Jeffrey W., A critical comparison of 3D experiments and simulations of tricalcium silicate hydration, Journal of the American Ceramic Society 101 (4), 1453-1470, 2018.\n\nA big thanks to Dr. Hu and Bret Robertson for their help on this work.\n\nThanks to Hailey Goodale! To learn more about EFT/Tapping visit http://petastapleton.com and http://evidencebasedeft.com\n\nReferences for this talk - \n\nChurch, Dawson, De Asis, Midanelle, and Brooks, Audrey.  \u201cBrief group intervention using EFT (Emotional Freedom Techniques) for depression in college students: A randomized controlled trial.\u201d Depression Research & Treatment (2012.) doi:10.1155/2012/257172\n\nStapleton, Peta et al. \u201cA feasibility study: Emotional freedom techniques for depression in Australian adults.\u201d Current Research in Psychology 5 (2014): 19-33. \n\nChatwin, Hannah. \u201cThe effectiveness of Cognitive Behavioural Therapy and Emotional Freedom Techniques in reducing depression and anxiety among adults: A pilot study.\u201d Integrative Medicine 15, no. 2 (2016): 27-34.\n\nNelms, J. and Castel, D. \u201cA systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized and non-randomized trials of Emotional Freedom Techniques (EFT) for the treatment of depression. \u201d  Explore: The Journal of Science and Healing 12 (2016) :  416-426. doi: 10.1016/j.explore.2016.08.001", "channelTitle": "Dr Peta Stapleton", "publishedAt": "2018-08-21T03:44:58Z"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "3", "viewCount": "484", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "commentCount": "2"}, "id": "nyDTfRFbEEI", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT9M27S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2016.08.001", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2016.08.001"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"title": "3D knot reconstruction within wooden boards", "description": "During the strength grading process of wooden boards in sawmills, nowadays, the use of laser scanning devices is already quite common. This results in grid-like fiber orientation data on all four board surfaces. A fully automated approach [1] is used to reconstruct the knot morphologies based on this data. This figure shows the identification of knot areas and subsequent division into knot sections after exclusion of insignificant small knots. The knots themselves are then modeled as rotationally symmetric cones. Their axes are found by iteratively connecting knot surfaces and\nminimizing previously defined knot measures. A simulated-annealing optimization scheme is employed to minimize the reconstruction error.\nThe reconstructed knot morphologies can now be used to calculate the local orthotropic material directions in any point of the board [2]. Following the so-called grain flow analogy, the longitudinal-tangential fiber directions can be determined by mimicking the trajectories of a laminar fluid flowing along the board axis, with knots as elliptical obstacles. The angle in radial-longitudinal direction is obtained from polynomials fitted to photographs of knot sections.\n\n[1] Kandler, G., Lukacevic, M., & F\u00fcssl, J. (2016). An algorithm for the geometric reconstruction of knots within timber boards based on fibre angle measurements. Construction and Building Materials, 124, 945-960. (https://doi.org/10.1016/j.conbuildmat.2016.08.001)\n[2] Lukacevic, M., & F\u00fcssl, J. (2014). Numerical simulation tool for wooden boards with a physically based approach to identify structural failure. European Journal of Wood and Wood Products, 72(4), 497-508. (https://doi.org/10.1007/s00107-014-0803-y)\n\n---\nResearch Unit of Simulation of Materials and Structures\nInstitute of Mechanics of Materials and Structures\nVienna University of Technology (TU Wien), Vienna, Austria", "channelId": "UCRiemJ-kXnSzyOgp1lvDijQ", "publishedAt": "2019-09-26T13:21:54Z", "channelTitle": "IMWS"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "viewCount": "21", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "-7wZE1Sl4a8", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT1M50S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2016.08.001", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2016.08.001"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"tags": ["Anthophora pueblo", "Anthophora", "Entomology"], "defaultAudioLanguage": "en", "channelId": "UCjU6ZwoTQtKWfz1urL7XcbA", "title": "Anthophora pueblo \u2013 the sandstone drilling bee", "description": "In the Southwestern deserts of United States, researchers discovered a new bee species: Anthophora pueblo. Unlike other bees, A. pueblo excavates sandstone nests. The bee uses its powerful mandibles and water to drill into soft sandstone. This is because the neurons and connections have not been modified. When the system is changed (ie. synaptic connection weights are modified (therefore affecting the internodal learning algorithms) or when neurons degenerate & are lost in disease), then the local mimimum in the search space landscape changes (new attractor point).\n\n\nI am interested in modelling various systems in the brain: \n--- MTL/Hippocampal/CA3 neural networks. Hopfield recurrent networks, attractor network, with pattern converging towards a common pattern (memory), based on initial cues. Auto-associative networks in CA3, content-addressable (not location-addressable) memory \u2013 re-construction of whole memory from one or more cues. Sparse code and system of overlaps \u2013 memories shared info (are associated) but non-spurious distinct memories can be formed from the system. Pattern separation and auto-association and pattern completion processes. Unsupervised self-organising topographic maps, STDP, rate coding, and oscillatory interference, for representation of allocentric space, context-based episodic memory, predictive navigation of scenes.\n--- V1-V4/V5 system of deep convolutional neural networks for visual feature representations.\n--- Limbic/Amygdala/OFC system for reward-based and aversion-based semi-supervised reinforcement learning.\n--- The PFC neural networks for top-down conscious decision-making.\n--- Somatosensory and somatomotor systems.\nsee https://www.bioneurotech.com\n\n\n\n\nSimBrain:\n\nhttp://simbrain.net/\nhttps://github.com/simbrain\n\nTosi Z, Yoshimi J (2016) \u201cSimbrain  3.0:  A  flexible,  visually-oriented  neural  network  simulator\u201d. [{"snippet": {"title": "Relaci\u00f3n entre la depresi\u00f3n y los ambientes en los que viven los estudiantes universitarios", "description": "El estr\u00e9s y la depresi\u00f3n en estudiantes universitarios tiene un \u00edndice bastante alto, lo que resulta en tendencias altas de suicidios, esto se debe a un punto extremo en que los estudiantes viven durante su tiempo acad\u00e9mico, que no est\u00e1 ligado \u00fanicamente a los estudios, sino a varios factores ya sea el consumo excesivo de alcohol, los problemas econ\u00f3micos o de problemas psicol\u00f3gicos, es necesario definir  las relaciones y  tendencias en personas con depresi\u00f3n mayor en textos cient\u00edficos para poder generar conciencia de los \u00edndices de suicidio  en estudiantes universitarios en la siguiente investigaci\u00f3n se evaluar\u00e1 distintos art\u00edculos cient\u00edficos que explican estas tendencias.\n\u00bfC\u00f3mo se relaciona los problemas del \u00e1mbito personal con el desempe\u00f1o  universitario y sus \u00edndices altos de suicidios en estudiantes latinoamericanos? \u200b.\n\nEn la investigaci\u00f3n realizada en universidades Brasile\u00f1as se detect\u00f3 que el 9.9% de los estudiantes entrevistados tuvieron ideas suicidas, resaltando entre sus causas los problemas de clase econ\u00f3mica, orientaci\u00f3n sexual y consumo de alcohol en la investigaci\u00f3n de la revista Latinoamericana Enfermagem en su art\u00edculo \u201cFactores asociados con la ideaci\u00f3n suicida entre estudiantes universitarios\u201d (Santos et al., 2017). A su vez en el art\u00edculo \u201cConsumo alcoh\u00f3lico de riesgo en estudiantes de tres universidades de la sierra central peruana\u201d se descubri\u00f3 que el 28% de estudiantes ten\u00edan se\u00f1ales de depresi\u00f3n, un 20% con casos de ansiedad y un 22% con \u00edndices de estr\u00e9s (Valdivia et al., 2018). De esta manera y con \u00edndices tan altos podemos decir que existe un problema que se debe investigar a fondo sobre las relaciones que conllevan a porcentajes altos.\n\nEn el art\u00edculo \u201cRelaci\u00f3n entre organizaci\u00f3n de personalidad y prevalencia de s\u00edntomas de depresi\u00f3n, ansiedad y estr\u00e9s entre universitarios de carreras de la salud\u201d  al hacer estudios con 356 estudiantes descartaron la relaci\u00f3n del g\u00e9nero o el tipo de carrera escogida ya que los \u00edndices mostraban que no exist\u00eda una relaci\u00f3n entre esos dos factores y los \u00edndices de depresi\u00f3n, por ello es necesario evaluar otros factores que llevan a la depresi\u00f3n en estudiantes universitarios de Latinoam\u00e9rica(Barraza et al., 2017), \nReferencias\n    Barraza-L\u00f3pez, Ren\u00e9, Mu\u00f1oz-Navarro, Nadia, & Contreras-Astorga, Ana. (2017). This video uses X-ray nano computed tomography and X-ray nano fluorescence to examine the structure and chemical composition of early age hydration at the nano length scale.  This video examines the variability of hydration of individual particles.  Next, the experiments look at the pore structure within the hydrated cement paste and finally, the work tracks how individual particles change over the first few hours of hydration and makes important insights into how the hydration products change.  \n\nMore details can be found in:\n\nHu, Q., Aboustait, M., Kim, T., Ley, M.T., Bullard, J., Scherer, G., Hanan, J.C., Rose, V., Winarski, R., Gelb, J., \u201cDirect Measurements of Structure, Chemistry and Mass Density During the Induction Period of C3S Hydration\u201d, Cement and Concrete Research, 2016, doi:10.1016/j.cemconres.2016.07.008.\n\nHu, Q.,  Aboustait, M., Kim, T., Ley, M.T., Hanan, J.C., Bullard, J., Winarski, R., Rose, V., \u201cDirect three-dimensional observation of the microstructure and chemistry of C3S hydration\u201d, Cement and Concrete Research, 2016, doi:10.1016/j.cemconres.2016.07.006.\n\n\nBullard, J.W., Hagedorn, J.H., Ley, M.T., Hu, Q., Griffin, W., Terrill, J.E., Jeffrey W., A critical comparison of 3D experiments and simulations of tricalcium silicate hydration, Journal of the American Ceramic Society 101 (4), 1453-1470, 2018.\n\nA big thanks to Dr. Hu and Bret Robertson for their help on this work.\n\nThanks to Hailey Goodale! Computers & Education, 10290-102. doi:10.1016/j.compedu.2016.07.006", "channelTitle": "Ariel Jade", "publishedAt": "2017-03-14T21:52:02Z"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "2", "viewCount": "89", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "commentCount": "1"}, "id": "xJz8ZGjTdSY", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT2M30S"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2016.07.006", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2016.07.006"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"title": "Profile of a Shooter", "description": "The killing of Cecil the lion (Panthera leo) ignited enduring and increasingly global discussion about trophy hunting (Nicholls 2015 Nature (doi:10.1038/ nature.2015.18101)). Yet, policy debate about its benefits and costs (e.g. (Di Minin et al. 2016 Trends Ecol. Evol. 31, 99\u2013102. (doi:10.1016/j.tree.2015. 12.006); Ripple et al. 2016 Trends Ecol. Evol. 31, 495\u2013496. (doi:10.1016/j. tree.2016.03.011)) focuses only on the hunted species and biodiversity, not the unique behaviour of hunters. Some contemporary recreational hunters from the developed world behave curiously, commonly targeting \u2018trophies\u2019: individuals within populations with large body or ornament size, as well as rare and/or inedible species, like carnivores (Darimont et al. 2015 Science 349, 858\u2013860. (doi:10.1126/science.aac4249)). Although contemporary hunters have been classified according to implied motivation (i.e. for meat, recreation, trophy, or population control; (Festa-Bianchet 2003 Animal Behavior and Wildlife Conservation (eds M Festa-Bianchet, M Apollonio), pp. 191\u2013 207); (Mysterud 2011 J. Appl. Ecol. 48, 827\u2013834. (doi:10.1111/j.1365-2664. 2011.02006.x))) as well the \u2018multiple satisfactions\u2019 they seek while hunting affiliation, appreciation, achievement; (Hendee 1974 Wildl. Soc. Bull. 2, 104\u2013113)), an evolutionary explanation of the motivation underlying trophy hunting has never been pursued. Too costly (difficult, dangerous) a behaviour to be common among other vertebrate predators, we postulate that trophy hunting is in fact motivated by the costs hunters accept. We build on empirical and theoretical contributions from evolutionary anthropology to hypothesize that signalling these costs to others is key to understanding, and perhaps influencing, this otherwise perplexing activity.", "channelId": "UC3upSp200VZGdhcIgyVlFew", "publishedAt": "2019-04-28T19:05:53Z", "channelTitle": "One State"}, "statistics": {"likeCount": "0", "viewCount": "8", "favoriteCount": "0", "dislikeCount": "0", "commentCount": "0"}, "id": "9SX_-LPNjQQ", "contentDetails": {"duration": "PT6M"}}], "idx_paper": "10.1016/j.media.2016.03.011", "q": "10.1016/j.media.2016.03.011"}, {"items": [{"snippet": {"tags": ["ylekioskijournal", "ylekioski", "yhteiskunta", "ilmi\u00f6", "society", "phenomenon"], "channelId": "UCtg939iTgYW2HaazqwW_BtQ", "title": "Haluan tonnini takaisin - Ilmastouutiset #4", "description": "ENERGIAPOLITIIKKA ON TAAS SEKSIK\u00c4ST\u00c4.\n\nUUSI JAKSO JOKA TOINEN TORSTAI.\n\nKOMMENTOI TILAA KANAVA TEE JOTAIN ENNEN KUIN MAAILMA TUHOUTUU.\n\n@ilmastouutiset\nyleareena https://areena.yle.fi/1-50007697\ninsta https://www.instagram.com/ilmastouuti...\ntwitter https://twitter.com/ilmastouutiset\n\nILMASTO ON AIKAMME ISOIN, MONIMUTKAISIN JA V***UMAISIN ONGELMA. A szerz\u0151 c\u00e9lja, hogy a n\u00e9z\u0151 megismerhesse ezeket az alternat\u00edv tudom\u00e1nyos n\u00e9zeteket. A vide\u00f3kban szerepl\u0151 inform\u00e1ci\u00f3kat mindenki saj\u00e1t felel\u0151ss\u00e9g\u00e9re haszn\u00e1lja, az edz\u00e9sm\u00f3dszereket, illetve a k\u00fcl\u00f6nb\u00f6z\u0151 \u2013 megszokott\u00f3l elt\u00e9r\u0151 \u2013 \u00e9letm\u00f3daj\u00e1nl\u00e1sokat egy\u00e9ni eg\u00e9szs\u00e9gi, fizikai \u00e1llapotnak megfelel\u0151en, a fokozatoss\u00e1g elv\u00e9t szem el\u0151tt tartva alkalmazza. Az oldalon le\u00edrtak egy eg\u00e9szs\u00e9gesebb, teljesebb \u00e9letmin\u0151s\u00e9g el\u00e9r\u00e9s\u00e9hez ny\u00fajtanak seg\u00edts\u00e9get, ugyanakkor alkalmaz\u00e1suk sor\u00e1n nem lehet figyelmen k\u00edv\u00fcl hagyni az egyedi ig\u00e9nyek felm\u00e9r\u00e9s\u00e9t \u00e9s az esetleges kock\u00e1zatok m\u00e9rlegel\u00e9s\u00e9t, megfelel\u0151 szakemberek, szakorvosok v\u00e9lem\u00e9nye alapj\u00e1n. Ha b\u00e1rmilyen eg\u00e9szs\u00e9g\u00fcgyi probl\u00e9m\u00e1d, s\u00e9r\u00fcl\u00e9sed van, gy\u00f3gyszert szedsz, k\u00e9rlek konzult\u00e1lj el\u0151bb az orvosoddal! I check whether their expectations were realistic by focussing on the difference between problem prevention and problem solving, applied to a number of clear human achievements. This then leads to a the role and structure of social values. Humans can exhibit multiple different value sets, but the currently dominant value set is very good in solving (isolated) problem, but bad in preventing problems. This leads to the hypothesis that humanity is concurrently at peak foolishness and peak intelligence. And hence ill-prepared for any future different than business as usual. \n\nReferences:\n\n- Andringa, T. C., & Angyal, N. (2019). \u05e8\u05d1 \u05de\u05e9\u05ea\u05e0\u05d4 \u05d4\u05db\u05d5\u05dc\u05dc \u05de\u05d9\u05df, \u05de\u05d3\u05d3 \u05de\u05e1\u05ea \u05d2\u05d5\u05e3 (BMI), \u05d4\u05d9\u05e4\u05d5\u05d8\u05e1\u05d8\u05d5\u05e1\u05d8\u05e8\u05d5\u05df, MELD \u05d5\u05d0\u05d8\u05d9\u05d5\u05dc\u05d5\u05d2\u05d9\u05d4 \u05e9\u05dc \u05e9\u05d7\u05de\u05ea, \u05e8\u05e7 \u05d4\u05d9\u05e4\u05d5\u05d8\u05d5\u05e1\u05d8\u05d5\u05e1\u05d8\u05e8\u05d5\u05e0\u05d9\u05de\u05d9\u05d4 (RR 2.76, p = 0.005) \u05d5- BMI (RR 0.88, p & lt; 0.001) \u05e0\u05e7\u05e9\u05e8\u05d5 \u05d1\u05d0\u05d5\u05e4\u05df \u05e2\u05e6\u05de\u05d0\u05d9 \u05dc\u05e1\u05e8\u05e7\u05d5\u05e4\u05e0\u05d9\u05d4.\n\u05de\u05e1\u05e7\u05e0\u05d4: \u05e8\u05de\u05d5\u05ea \u05d8\u05e1\u05d8\u05d5\u05e1\u05d8\u05e8\u05d5\u05df \u05e0\u05de\u05d5\u05db\u05d5\u05ea \u05e7\u05e9\u05d5\u05e8\u05d5\u05ea \u05dc\u05e1\u05e8\u05e7\u05d5\u05e4\u05e0\u05d9\u05d4 \u05d4\u05db\u05d5\u05dc\u05dc\u05ea \u05e2\u05dc\u05ea\u05d4 (MAD + 0.08 kg, CI +0.01; 0.15 kg, p = 0.009) \u05d5\u05db\u05da \u05d2\u05dd \u05e6\u05e4\u05d9\u05e4\u05d5\u05ea \u05d4\u05de\u05d9\u05e0\u05e8\u05dc\u05d9\u05dd \u05d1\u05e2\u05e6\u05dd \u05d1\u05e6\u05d5\u05d5\u05d0\u05e8 \u05d4\u05d9\u05e8\u05da. \u05d4\u05d4\u05de\u05d5\u05d2\u05dc\u05d5\u05d1\u05d9\u05df You may have heard that the eyes are the window to the brain. This is because your eyes are direct extensions of your brain that sprout out during development. Then, we rely on our visual system to tell us where we are in space and what is around us. In order to map our world, we need the ability to move our eyes to see it. This requires a large amount of brain activity from many areas that are interconnected through brain circuits. When one part of the brain is not functioning well, we can identify and rehabilitate that area via eye movements. Check out the video for more in depth information on the different types of eye movements and how they can be used for diagnosis and treatment!\nLappi, O. This video looks at two siblings who were separated at birth and exposed to different environmental influencers and familial lifestyles. Specifically, it examines the relationship between obesity and factors such as local groceries, urban industrial parks, digital screen time and family dinners. Os curcumin\u00f3ides s\u00e3o compostos fen\u00f3licos comumente usados \u200b\u200bcomo tempero, pigmento e aditivo, tamb\u00e9m utilizados como agente terap\u00eautico usado em v\u00e1rios alimentos. Pesquisas\ud83d\udd2c abrangentes ao longo do s\u00e9culo passado revelaram v\u00e1rias fun\u00e7\u00f5es importantes dos curcumin\u00f3ides\ud83e\udd17.\n\nV\u00e1rios estudos \ud83d\udcd6\ud83e\uddeapr\u00e9-cl\u00ednicos de cultura de c\u00e9lulas e animais sugerem que os curcumin\u00f3ides t\u00eam extensa atividade biol\u00f3gica como antioxidante, neuroprotetor, antitumor, anti-inflamat\u00f3rio, anti-acidog\u00eanico, radioprotetor e artrite\ud83d\ude33.\n\nDiferentes ensaios cl\u00ednicos\ud83d\udd2c\ud83e\uddea tamb\u00e9m sugerem um potencial papel terap\u00eautico para os curcumin\u00f3ides em in\u00fameras doen\u00e7as cr\u00f4nicas, como c\u00e2ncer de c\u00f3lon , c\u00e2ncer de pulm\u00e3o, c\u00e2ncer de mama, doen\u00e7as inflamat\u00f3rias intestinais.\n\nOs curcumin\u00f3ides s\u00e3o o composto natural \ud83c\udf3f\ud83c\udf43promissor com uma grande variedade de propriedades terap\u00eauticas, principalmente alvos e intera\u00e7\u00f5es biol\u00f3gicas, ligados a in\u00fameras doen\u00e7as.\n\nNa revis\u00e3o \ud83d\udcd6 realizada pelo Centro R&D da Aurea Biolabs na India em 2016 os pesquisadores destacam as propriedades dos curcumin\u00f3ides, no uso isolado ou em associa\u00e7\u00e3o com outra forma modificada, demonstrando serem eficazes no tratamento neuroprotetor, antitumoral, antioxidante, anticancer\u00edgeno, anti-inflamat\u00f3rio, anti-acidog\u00eanico, radioprotetor, infec\u00e7\u00f5es sexualmente transmiss\u00edveis, anti-esof\u00e1gico, anti-nefrotoxicidade, antimicrobiano, antiviral, anti-angiog\u00eanico, anti-proliferativo, anti-imunomodulador, hepatoprotetor, antimal\u00e1rico, anti-toxicidade e propriedades anti-diab\u00e9ticas. \ud83d\ude0d\n\nFonte: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jtcme.2016.05.005\n\nPara saber mais sobre o PODER DOS \u00d3LEOS ESSENCIAIS\ud83c\udf43 \u00e9 s\u00f3 chamar!\n\nGostou? deixe seu coment\u00e1rio e compartilhe com que voc\u00ea ama!\u2764", "channelTitle": "Dra. First, I need to introduce what the term Nyonya means! Basically, Nyonya cuisine originates from the Peranakans, descendants of early Chinese migrants who went to Malaysia, and married local Malay women over 500 years ago. They were also known as the Straits Chinese, who settled in Malacca, Penang and Singapore. Female Peranakans are known as nyonyas, while men are called babas. Basically, my ancestors hopped on a boat from the Fujian Province in China, in search of a better life and landed in a small coastal town in Malaysia called Malacca. I am a sixth generation Straits born Chinese.\n\nThe language of the Peranakans, Baba Malay, is a dialect of the Malay language, containing many Hokkien words. Its use is mainly limited to the older generation. However, English has replaced baba malay as the main language spoken amongst the younger generation. Therefore, I cannot speak any Chinese (even though I look ethnically Chinese), and have been called a banana (yellow on the outside and white on the inside!). The Malay phrase \"Orang Cina Bukan Cina\", which literal translation means, \"Chinese but not Chinese\" captures the relationship between the Peranakan and Chinese identity.\n\nIn the past, nyonya girls were not educated in schools and were trained to be amazing cooks and skilled in embroidery from young. They were expected to look after the home and prepare for marriage. In those days, matchmakers played an important role. They would arrive the home at 10 am, to listen to the sound of spices being pounded by the prospective bride, in the mortar and pestle (batu lesong/tumbuk). Apparently, one would be able to tell if the person was a good cook by the rhythm and sound of the pounding. I am so thankful I was not born during that time as I would fail miserably! Today, we also simplify our lives by using a food processor to blend all our spices.\n\nNyonya food is complicated and can take years to master. Nyonya recipes are also handed down from one generation to the next. My mom does not use written recipes with measurements. All ingredients are measured via estimates (agak agak). Basically, you had to learn how to cook by observing and practicing. It\u2019s only recently that I have asked my mom to quantify ingredients (in which she just replies with \u201cone or two tablespoons\u201d or a \u201chandful\u201d. I literally bring out my weighing scale or measuring spoons to measure the ingredients when she puts it aside!\n\nSignature ingredients in nyonya recipes are usually spicy, and use numerous pungent roots such as galangal, turmeric and ginger; aromatic leaves (kaffir lime, pandan, curry and laksa leaves); and other ingredients such as shallots, lemongrass, shrimp paste (belacan) and chillies. There are many other spices that I do not cover in this video, namely, torch ginger buds (bunga kantan), candle nuts (buah keras), buah keluak, tamarind (asam jawa), coriander seeds (ketumbar), betel leaves (daun kaduk),  galangal leaves, and coriander leaves, which are also common in nyonya cooking.\n\nThese spices and herbs are common in Asia, but quite expensive in Australia. Hence, many of these ingredients are imported frozen from Vietnam and available in the Asian grocery store. I personally freeze all my herbs and spices in Melbourne (e.g., lemongrass, pandan leaves, kaffir lime leaves, chilli, ginger, galangal, turmeric) so that I have stock at home all the time! I also use readily frozen shredded lemongrass and galangal in my cooking (think of time saving)! When chillies are cheap, I buy it to blend and freeze.\n\nOverall, Peranakan or Nyonya cuisine is extremely popular in Asia. If you haven't tried this cuisine, I encourage you to visit a Nyonya restaurant the next time you visit Malacca, Penang or Singapore. The food is truly a unique blend of Malay, Chinese and other Southeast Asian cultures!\n\nReferences: \nLee, C.K. (1974). Mrs. Lee's cookbook: Nonya recipes and other favourite recipes. Eurasia Press. Singapore\n\nNg, C.Y. & Karim, S.A. (2016). Historical and contemporary perspectives of the Nyonya food culture in Malaysia. Journal of Ethnic Foods. \"Red Chillis\" by weegolo is licensed under CC BY-NC 2.0\n\nSong credit\nBe Happy \u00b7 AShamaluevMusic https://youtu.be/Lw_su43UQn4", "channelTitle": "Carol Tan\u2019s Kitchen", "publishedAt": The question is, what do we learn about the brain from these huge data sets?\n\n\"Distributed coding of choice, action and engagement across the mouse brain.\"\nNicholas A.
